Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	Having completed this book for you, my son, which is the last of the sciences in medicine with its complement, and having reached the end of it through its expositions and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since operation with the hand has been neglected in our region and time, and perhaps the science of it has entirely perished and its trace has been lost, and only a few small descriptions remain in ancient books which have been changed by hand: and they have suffered error and doubt until their intentions were closed and its vision was lengthened. It seemed to me that I should revive it with the order of this treatise in it according to the way of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation: and that I should come with the forms of Cauterii's tools, and other instruments of work: because it is made from its addition of declaration, and its operation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good craftsman of it is not found with his own hand in our time is because the art of medicine is long, and one must be exercised in its author before that in the science of anatomy which Galen narrated, until he knows the joints of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and tendons, and their number, and their exit, and the pulsatilium of veins, and quiet places, and the exits of their places.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for that reason Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	But we have already spoken about that in the introduction of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since those who are not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy cannot be purged from error, and will fall into the error by which men perish: just as I have seen many from among them who are formed from this science, and boast of it without knowledge, and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Which is, because I have seen a stupid doctor cut an abscess of the scrophula on the neck of a woman, and he cut some arteries in the neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed, until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another doctor who presumed to extract a stone from a man who had grown old, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he reached him, and extracted it with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself had already been called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone, and the weakness of the man, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another doctor who received a bribe from a certain duke of our land for medicine: and it happened to the black eunuch who was with him, a fracture near the calcaneum of his leg: and the doctor rushed with his ignorance, and he bound the fracture over the wound with cotton, and stars, and a strong bandage, and did not let out the wound's expiration.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he healed him according to his own desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he sent him away for several days, and commanded him not to untie the bandage: and it stayed like that until his leg was an abscess, and his foot, and it reached his destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	Then I was called to him: and I rushed to untie the bandage: and there followed peace, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption was already confirmed in the member: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, the corruption ceased to walk in the member until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who punctured the cancerous abscess: and it became an ulcer after days, until its wickedness was revealed to its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	Which is to say, because when the cancer is pure from melancholic humor, then it is not necessary for it to reach him with iron at all, unless there is in the member that can bear, so that the whole of it be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And because of this, my son, it is necessary for you to know that the operation with hand is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation to which health is associated, and the operation, with which there is danger in many arrangements.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already awakened in every place of this book, in which the operation comes, in which there is fear and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that, and leave it: so that the fool may not find a way to speak, and disgrace.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Take therefore the measure with solicitude and protection, and your infirm ones with facility and firmness, and use the better way leading to salvation and laudable success through the grace of God: and leave terrible difficulties of healing: and take away your souls from that which makes you fear, so that hesitancy may enter upon you in your faith and your good.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is rather remaining to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galenus has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You shall not apply harmful remedies: lest you be called bad physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have, however, divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter One: On the use of fire and sharp medicine, arranged from beginning to end, including the forms of instruments and tools for cauterization, and all that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter Two: On cutting and piercing, bloodletting and incision, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and similar things; and all arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Chapter Three: On restoration, and dislocation, and the cure of twisting, and similar things; arranged from beginning to end, and according to the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On cauterization and its harm, and with which constitutions it is suitable, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	However, before I mention the operation with it, it is necessary to tell of the quality of its cauterization and its harm: and in which constitution it should be shown.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the speech about the quality of cauterization and its harm is a long and subtle science, and an occult secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	For indeed there was much talk about it among the wise men, and they disagreed in it: and to me, however, it is not enough from their words, fearing prolongation.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cauterization brings universally to every constitution, which is with matter, and without matter: excepting two constitutions, which are the constitution hot without matter, and the constitution dry without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in a hot and dry compound with matter, they separated.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For indeed some said that the cauterizing iron of the juvenile was in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of that, namely that the cauterizing iron is not suitable for the ailment, which is from heat and dryness: because the nature of fire is heat: and unsuitable, so as to be healed from the ailment hot and dry, with hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the opposite of that: that through cauterizing, a cure is made in every hot and dry ailment which occurs in human bodies: because when you compare the body of man, and his humidities, to the compound of fire, you find the body of man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And indeed I say by his speech: because from experiment he has extracted that from me many times already.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not necessary, unless he who has already been tested, and exercised in the chapter of cauterization exercise lastly, and knows the diversity of human compounds, and the disposition of ailments in themselves, and their causes, and their accidents, and the time of them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But from other compounds there is no fear on you: and especially in cold and wet ailments.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For indeed all doctors have now gathered on them: and they did not separate in the cure with cauterizing in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, O sons, that from the secret of the cure with cauterizing and fire, and its goodness over cauterizing with burning medicine is: because fire is simple, whose action does not reach, except to the member which is being cauterized: and it does not harm another member joined with it, unless a small harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of medicine has reached the point where it extends beyond the members: and perhaps it causes difficulty in healing a member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	However, fire due to its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do that unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now indeed we have become aware of that through experience, because of the length of service and study with the art, and the position on the truth of things: and for that reason I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not, because it is not allowed to this my book, I would bring you a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies for its expulsion, which expels difficulties demonstrated by philosophical speech, which would be remembered by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they themselves disagree at the time when it is fitting to do cauterization, and put a better time for true.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say, that cauterization is fitting at all times: because the accidental harm is submerged in benefit, which is drawn with the cauterizer.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Especially if cauterization is for pain from necessary pains, strong, urgent ones who do not tolerate slowness: because it is feared from them that something evil may happen which is greater than the small harm that comes through time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And may not fall into your minds, sons, that which they do not fear, namely the common people and stupid doctors, namely that to the pain which is healed by cauterization, there is not always return: and they put this consequence, and the thing is not as they think: because cauterization is not, except in the place of medicine, which changes the complexion, and dries the humidities which are the cause why pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, the cauterizing instrument exceeds medicine by its speed of healing, and its effectiveness of operation, and its forcefulness of dominance: and it is possible that the sickness returns at some hour of a time according to the temperament of the infirm, and the location of his sickness, and its virtue: and that which is prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluities in him: and that which reaches him in his acquisition of it from foods, and similar ones to those, unless sickness occurs, in which the cauterizing is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Subtle sickness in a member of few superfluities, and moistures, such as the cauterizing of the tooth, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that that pain does not return in him.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But truly the talk of the common people again, that the cauterizing is the last of medicine, is right: not to that which they intend in it: because they believe that there is no cure which confers with medicine, nor with another after the falling of the cauterizing.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the thing is contrary to that, and intent, that the cauterizing is the last of medicine, is not, unless when we administer modes of cure in some sickness, and those medicines do not confer: then we administer at the end of the matter cauterizing, and it confers: then from there it falls, that the cauterizing is the last of medicine, not according to the understanding which the common people and many stupid physicians intend.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients said, that the cauterizing with gold is better than the cauterizing with iron: and they did not say that, unless because of the equality of gold, and sublimity of its substance: and they said, that it does not make a pus place of the cauterizing.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	However, it is not absolutely true that I have already proven and discovered that this does not work in certain bodies without other things.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery iron itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you use the cautery iron in fire from gold, it is not declared to you when it burns according to the quantity you want, because of the redness of gold: and when it rushes to the heat, and if you add more fire to it, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls from this into his trade: and for that reason, the cautery iron with iron is faster and closer to us in relation to the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And indeed, I have already arranged this Chapter on the Cautery in order according to chapters, and I have arranged them from the head to the feet, so that those seeking something from it may find it easily.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterying the Head at the Commissural Line.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cautery application gives control over moisture and cold above the brain: which are two causes of sweat, and a multitude of fluids flowing from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and a multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain, and general all kinds of discomfort that occur from cold, such as paralysis, and sweating, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar illnesses to these diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterying is that you order the sick person: so that he may be emptied in the first place with a cleansing solution for the head three nights, or four, according to the strength of the sick person, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your thumb on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever your middle finger reaches that spot, mark that location with an unclean (mark).
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the cauterizing iron, which has this shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with the unclean (mark), with a downward movement, by which your hand is gradually constricted, and you turn it back.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly withdraw your hand, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the bone quantity of the head is already detached, or the quantity of zeuberg, then withdraw your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with another from it if it is cooled: until the bones that I told you about are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it with the wound: and put it on that spot, and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the salve on top of that which was drunk with butter, and leave it on the spot until the scar of the fire is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with the quadripharmacon ointment, until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that the more the wound remains open, the more it emits pus: therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized until the bone: and the cauterizing iron should be held until something of the thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then, after it has been set and become hardened from the bone, it should be dressed.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Some say that it is necessary to apply the cautery directly to the bone until an impression is made in the bone, so that the bone falls off as if by a kirate: or with an instrument similar to one used by women for writing small letters: and they believe that vapors from the head will escape from this place, and the wound will be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be dressed until it has become hardened.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	In my opinion, these two kinds of cautery are not seen at all in all men except in certain men according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And it is better to leave it alone with its own health, in my opinion.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened from the solution of its own natural continuity: as we have shown in other members: and especially when the head of an infirm person is weak by nature: and indeed the first kind of cautery is more saving and better for me, and I use it: therefore work with it in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing the head in pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When pain in the whole head is chronic and prolonged in an infirm person, and he uses herbs, and coals, and purgatives, and oils, and fomentations.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if he has already been cauterized with one cautery, which we have mentioned, and does not give him anything from those: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the infirm person is strong by nature, and is not weak, and has found a violent cold: then cauterize with another cautery under it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it above all the horns of its own head with the cautery, so that it does not pass through the skin, and a quantity of bone is exposed, as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And burn it with a single cauterizing tool at the back of its head, in the place called the 'navel': and it is the location where the windpipe is placed. And lift up your mat (or bed) in this, and do not uncover its mouth.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For indeed it found itself due to this intense pain, and different from the pain of all other cauterizations of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this Cauterium in its place: and it is necessary that it be a cauterizing tool, by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of its head more subtly with a cauterizing tool, by which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing in hemicrania, both with the burning drug and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it happens that pain and swelling occur in a part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and is evacuated with cleansing drugs for the head, and the rest of the cure, which I said in the divisions of ailments, and not all of it: then cauterization in that is according to two methods: either cauterization with a sharp burning drug: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But the cauterizing tool with a sharp burning drug is, as you take one tooth of garlic, and scrape it, and cut off its ends from two sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of the pain at the time with a wide lancet, until it becomes in it a place under the skin, in which the tooth is caught.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it into that under the skin, until it is hidden: then bind it above with a suitable amount of cotton, and release it after fifteen hours, and remove the garlic, and let it rest for two or three days: afterwards put butter soaked cloth on top of it, until the place becomes pus: then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines which I have written about in my twelfth treatise on burning remedies.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Indeed, the cautery of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The cauterizing iron, which has this shape.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Claw: because the shape of its head is like the shape of a claw, in which there is something curved, and in the middle of it is a small elevation.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand: and you will turn the iron gradually with speed: and the quantity that is burned from the thickness of the skin, is like its middle.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that the artery which is below does not burn, and blood flows.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then dip the wound in salt water, and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days: then place the wound with butter: afterwards care with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cautery this hemicrania with the second edge of the knife of the cauterizer.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And avoid from incision of the artery in this hemicrania, not anciently proper.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	§ On the manner of cauterying in ancient hemicrania.
Caput V.	Head V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating hemicrania, with that which we said from the previous cure, and what we said in divisions of ailments, and it does not benefit him: and you see from the ailment, that it is not sufficient to him what we said from the first cauterizing with medicine, or with cauterizer with fire, then it is necessary to burn the knife cauterizer, until it becomes white after the signs of pain on the spot, whose length is the middle of the finger, or rather that: and place your hand one vice [?] and stretch it until you cut the artery, and reach up to the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to guard against the continuation of the jawbone, which moves during mastication, lest it be burned or a nerve that moves it be affected, from which spasm may arise.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And let this be over the guard and the precaution of the flow of blood from the artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its division there is fear, and especially for him who does not know what it does, and is not eager or experienced: and he leaves the operation with him first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with the remembrance of the management of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own way, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	But if you see from the pain that this cauterizer does not suffice for him, and you see the weak body bearing the cauterizer in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, care for the wound until he is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cauterizer that we said in the chapter of extracting the artery with a cauterizer having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more suitable.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	About the method of cauterizing in pain of the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens that pain occurs in the ear from cold, and is cured with solutions, and the other cure that we said in division, and the pain is not removed, then cauterize with fire: and this is called a punctum, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then puncta with it after its ignition in the circumference of the ear entirely, as it is turned around: or in the circumference of both, if the pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And draw yourself away from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the places with the cauterizer: and let the quantity of the cauterizer be ten puncta in every ear, and so.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the affected areas until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the method of cauterizing in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture that is cured with cauterization is only from certain species that occur from phlebitis, as we mentioned in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And the lack of cauterization of this species, which occurs from dryness and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of torture with honey, and headpurges, and gargarisms, and your cure does not help, then it is necessary for you to cauterize the sick person with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and second somewhat lower from his temple, and third at the connection of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterization on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Since softening does not occur, except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is, to cauterize the same cauterization instrument directly at the tip of the upper ear under the horn of the head somewhat: and another in the temple, whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cauterization instrument until half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterization instrument, and it is a species from a knife, whose form was mentioned before: however, it is not too thin, as you see: and it should be that the knife is somewhat lacking in thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the affected areas, with what preceded, until healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When ancient apoplexy is cured, and you treat it with what we mentioned, and your medication does not help, and the sick person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizations over all the horn of his head, and with the cauterization instrument in the middle of his head, as we mentioned, and with the cauterization instrument in the back of his head, according to what preceded: and the mode of cauterization should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Even the lip of the stomach is cauterized with a cautery: and it is more distant.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it should be treated, with what came before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterizing in Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the jar great amounts of hiera picra and cleansing pills be given first, and they cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the sick person all over, and place on his occipital bone the plaster described in the treatise on plasters: and place it repeatedly.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is indeed the method of cauterization: and do it according to the order which I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by this, good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then do to him three cauterizations in the posterior part of his head, which are descending from the superior part of his head down to the lower part of the eye: and place between every cauterization the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization, with what came before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you wish to add, and the sick person is able to tolerate it: then do to him cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If however you wish to add: then cauterize him on two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him, until he is healed: and the cauterization should be oily according to the form which was mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head with hiera picra, and with what we said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize him in the middle of his head, and with cauterization on every horn of his head, and with cauterization on his posterior, and three on his spinal processes.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If you lack the necessary skills in mollification of the body and are weak in tolerating pain, and the sickness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the spines of his back, and the last one with the cauteri, until most of his skin is burned off, and lift your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him until he recovers: and thus use the cauteri.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic should not be cauterized unless he is one whose epilepsy is caused by phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, you must first cleanse his brain with hyeris, and with the rest of the cure that we mentioned in the division, when he is weak, or unable to bear medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If he is a child who cannot bear medicines, then give him a gargle, and cleansing mouthpieces to cleanse his brain, before many days with good nourishment.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, and then cauterize him with a single cauteri in the middle of his head, according to what preceded in method: and with another cauteri in the back of his head, and on every horn of his head with a cauteri.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If he is weak and able to bear it, then cauterize him with the cauteries that I mentioned in having paralysis, and mollification of the body on the spines of his neck, and the spines of his back: and let the cauteri be olive according to the method that preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If he is a child who is weak, then place a thin cauteri according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries that we mentioned for one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of humors flowing down to melancholy, and there is a weak humid body, then give it a drink that cleanses its brain, according to what preceded in division: then shave the weak head, and make afterwards a well-made tortellini from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the weak one sitting squared should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more fitting from old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a fire with temperate heating measure, which the finger could tolerate when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then wash it out in the middle of its head in a circle, and let it go until it is cooled down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the weak one once a week, with good regimen of his other things, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small points as much as possible of it, except that you hold your hand with the cauterizer: indeed it is scented.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cauterization moistens the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a wet cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	About the way of cauterizing in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water is declared to you in the eye by signs, which I said in division, then begin and give the weak one a drink, with that which will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard it from all moistures, and make it sit in the bath, on fasting days for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to roast his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two temples with two cauteries, if there is the beginning of descent of water into both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is the beginning of water in one eye: and cut off with the cautery all veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let the cauterization be long in the width of the temples: and beware of blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them off, and precaution against blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the back, under two bones, with two last-produced cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in the tears of olden times.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are olden, constant: and they are over veins, and arteries which are in manifestly the outside of the head, it is verified that that is from excessive cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the cautery which I have mentioned in the beginning of water descending, cauterization in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries over two temples, and with two cauterizations in the back under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you lack addition, then cauterize it on all side with caution the eye, over the extreme end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in the pus of the nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that which we mentioned in the division, and medication does not help: then hasten, and give the weak person a decoction of three nights: afterwards shave his head, and cauterize it with a medium cauterizer, with an oil lamp.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a clawed cauterizer, with two cauterizers, above two eyebrows under the hair slightly.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the clawed cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in the softening of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened from pain or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with a single cauterizer, with this lunar cauterizer.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above two eyebrows slightly with two cauterizers in every part: and they should be lengthened from two temples: and the length of all cauterizers should be according to the lengths of the eyebrows: and do not extend your hand with the cauterizer, but according to the quantity that burns the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cauterizer according to this method of the lunar cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Concerning the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs are facing away from the eye and are sharp.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cauterizer in that is according to two methods: either a cauterizer with fire: or a cauterizer with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the cauterizer with fire, order the sick person before it, so that he may let go of his hairs, if it is from those who shave them, until they are lengthened and equalized.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they are pricked by them at the time of their birth: then bind his eyes with a bandage, so that they do not move, until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore they are born and equalized, then place the head of the sick person in your lap: afterwards mark the eyelids with a pencil, with the sign that it is according to the form of the myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a wet cloth soaked in egg white: or in the mucilage of psyllium on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then with a cauterizing iron, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize above the sign that you marked on the eyelids many times, until the surface of the skin is burned, which is like the form of the myrtle leaf, entirely visible.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the health of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted, and the hairs raised near the puncture of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Raise therefore your hand then: and let him go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place on him a cloth with butter, until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment, until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If however some of the hairs return after an hour, and the eyelid is softened: then repeat the cauterizing iron on that place, as you did in the first time.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize that, until it is raised to its natural place: and equalized so that they do not prick the eye with the hairs.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ On how to cauterize with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you command the sick person, that he let go of the hairs, until they lengthen and equalize.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make a shape of a leaf from paper and cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take equal amounts of known soap and dry, unmixed powdered chalk, each weighing one ounce or about that amount: then grind them together well, and make it into a paste quickly, so that it does not harden.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take a piece of the paste from the one you made and spread it on the paper in the shape of a leaf, and place it on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a wet compress soaked in egg white: and let the sick person rest in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the remedy and press it gently.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And move it whenever the sick person feels the bite of the remedy, for its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	And while he continues to feel this bite that he found, then remove the remedy and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	And when the bite stops, then remove the remedy and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider whether you see the eyelid swelling, as it does with contraction with fire or with incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat over it from the remedy on the place where it does not press the remedy and does not stain, until your operation equals and the eye closes.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place a wet compress with butter on it until the skin burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with diaphanicon ointment or another one, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation to guard the last guardianship, lest something fall into the eye from the remedy.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after days and something fights from the hair in the eye, then repeat the remedy on that place which softens from the eyelid properly, as you did in the first place.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of yourself until you are healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that human eyes differ in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to that, your consideration should be: and the path of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a desire for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	About the method of cauterizing in a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating a fistula, since as we said in the divisions of diseases, and your cure does not combine: then, it is necessary for you to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head between his hands in this way, so that he does not move, nor move his head with his own.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a compress soaked in white of egg, or in a mucilage of psyllium on his eye: then ignite the cauterizing iron, whose shape is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be concave, like the shape of a quill pen's feather from one end, with which it is made into a cauterizing iron: and if you wish it to be penetrating up to the other end, and if you wish it to be upwards, then try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this concave is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and extract the pus from it, and dry it: and if it is not open, then open it, and extract the pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place then on it the cauterizing iron, which is made to burn very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold with it your hand for a little by the cauterizing iron from the eye, to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not wander, or disturb the sick person: and place the cauterizing iron in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you reach the beginning of your cauterizing instrument up to the mouth, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	But if not, then repeat the cauterizing instrument once or twice, depending on what you need from it, and let it rest for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a bandage with butter on it, and care for it with drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days have passed and it has not healed: then place a sharp corrosive medicine on it until the mouth is opened: and shave it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Bend to the place of the fistula, and find it: then place in it a fine cannula, that is, a fine needle, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour in it a quantity of drachma of melted lead, and hold your hand with the cannula with good retention, and not move it at all weakly, so that it does not run or reach the melted lead to its eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And you should place on the weak eye's bandage an infused bandage on white of egg or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	But if the fistula is healed, with what we said from cauterizing and curing, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	But if not, then it is necessary to administer the nostril hole, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what comes in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in lip splits.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many times it happens in lip splits, which are called hairs, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you are concerned with these wounds, since as we said in the division of diseases, and there is no cure, then a small knife heated by fire, in this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its hollowness according to the thinness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it quickly in these wounds, until the heated knife reaches the depth of the wounds.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a poultice, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in a mouth ulcer.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus, and bursts: afterwards it becomes putrid, and pus runs out, and a fistula is formed: then care for it, and there is no cure for it, then it is necessary to use a heated knife according to the amount that can be taken into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert it into the hole of the fistula, and hold your hand until the heated knife reaches the depth and end of it, and do it once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it after that, with what we said about cure until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is cut off, and it is healed, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place, and remove the bone of the decayed part according to what comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in the gums, and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened due to moisture, and the teeth move, and you care for it with medicines, and there is no cure: then place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then, place the cauterizing iron, whose shape will be described later, on top of the tooth: and quickly insert the hot cauterizing instrument into it: and hold your hand there for a moment, until you feel the weak heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And then lift your hand: and then repeat the cauterizing instrument several times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the weak person will fill their mouth with salt water, and hold it for one hour: and then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened by movement, and the gums are softened and contracted, and the corrupted moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing in tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to coldness, or there is frost in it, or worms, and no cure is found with medicines: then the cauterizing instrument is used in two ways: either with butter: or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the cauterizing instrument with butter is, that you take boiled butter in an iron spoon, or in a brass vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a cloth, and cover it over the outer part of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in the boiled butter: and place it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools: then repeat it several times, until the power of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse a cloth, or a rag in cold butter, and place it on the painful tooth: and place a burning iron on top of it: until the fire reaches the deep hollow of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But the cauterizing with fire is, that you direct it towards the nozzle of air, or the nozzle of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something rough on his body, so that the sharpness of fire does not reach the mouth of the sick person.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then place the cautery, which will come in the shape of a cautery, on his tooth: and hold your hand over it until the cautery is cooled down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed, either on that same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary for the sick person to fill his mouth with good beurage after the impression of that cautery, and hold it for an hour: then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cautery with whatever extremity you can, according to what is possible: and this is the shape of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterying in strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When strophuli are from phlegm, and from cold humors, and are not obedient to digestion by medicines, and you want to quickly digest them: then place a flat cautery on fire, which has this shape.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that the smoke comes out from the cautery by the other extremity: and place it on fire over the abscess once, and secondly, if you need it, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then place the cautery according to the amount of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it go for three days, and place on it a soft infusion in butter, until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with tooth ointment, until the shape of the tube heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterying in a hoarse voice, and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moistures accumulate over the bronchial canal, and especially when it is accompanied by a cold constitution, then it is necessary for the sick person to be evacuated first with dissolved remedies.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize the affected part at the root of the throat in a depressed place: and beware, do not let the cauterizer reach the throat, nor in the skin, unless something of it.
