Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Frequently it happens that the flow of blood from an artery which is cut at the wound, which happens outside, or at the incision of the pustule, or cauterizing the limb, and similar to them: and it is difficult to remove it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when it happens to someone, then quickly with your hand at the mouth of the artery, and put on top of your finger: and press it much, until the blood is held back by your finger, and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put a small cautery of olive oil and many: and blow on them, until they are burned greatly.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or a little, or much, according to the wound and the place in which the artery is broken, and put the cautery on the vein, after you remove your finger quickly: and hold the cautery, until the blood is cut.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If the thorn is expelled from the orifice of the artery and the burning iron is extinguished, then take another burning iron quickly from the prepared ones in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not cease to do this with one after another until the blood stops flowing.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, lest you burn the nerves which are there, and another misfortune occurs on the weak one.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is impossible to remove it: especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a burning iron, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is removed, the ends of it contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is tied with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or they are placed on it medicines of their property, which is to cut off the blood and tie it with a proper compression.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But he who administers its cutting with a ligature and binding with a cloth, and position of things burning and similar, does not give it to him completely, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if it happens to anyone of that, and he is not present to him the physician nor the medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the orifice of the vein itself, as we said, and compression of it very, until oppressed by the blood from the upper part of the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger is not removed, above it with cold water of intense cold always, until the blood freezes, and swells, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider in it what is needed from the burning iron, or from the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	Chapter One: The Beginning of Surgery
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part Two
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	Chapter on Incision, Puncture, and Bloodletting in Wounds and Similar Conditions
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already mentioned in Chapter One, all illness that is suitable for the application of fire and burning medicine, and its causes, reasons, instruments, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed chapters from the head to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I proceed in this chapter the same way: so that it may alleviate those who are seeking and have found it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary for you to learn this, son, which is in this chapter from the fear of that which is in Chapter One about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that reason, it is necessary to have greater caution in it, because in the operation which is in this chapter, often feces and blood fall out together, with which life stands at the opening of the vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of the exit, or cure of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision on a stone, and all similar things: from all of these, fear, trembling, and death fall in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you not to fall into that in which there is hesitation, for sometimes such men and their ways of infirmity come to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is one who becomes angry with his illness, and is light-hearted about death: because of the vehemence of him which he found from his infirmity and length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with illness is from fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	Among them is one who gives his lute to you, and gives you along with it, hoping for health, but his illness is dangerous.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, it is not necessary to consent to him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more urgent than his greed and your greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him unless after certain knowledge that confirms to you the succession of praiseworthy.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use them in the healing of all your sick, for the prediction and indication of what is fitting for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him you have help for the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O son, His understanding, and may He not take from you direction and inspiration, for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the previous chapter of Cauterization, from the head to the feet: so that you may be relieved of what you seek from him and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ On the healing of water that gathers in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this weakness often happens to children among those who are born: or when the midwife tightly holds the head of the child without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it happens even for an unknown cause that is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And indeed I have not seen this illness in other than children: and to all of whom I saw from them, death came quickly: therefore it seemed to me to leave the operation in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	I myself have seen a boy whose head was filled with water, and his head was admired every day until he could no longer sit on himself due to the size of his head: and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture either accumulates between the skin and bone, or beneath the bone above the skull.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation for this, if the moisture is between the skin and bone, and it is a small abscess, then it must be cut in the middle of the head: and the length of the fissure should be about two knots, until the moisture is drained.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a syringe.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then place these two fissures according to this shape.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the cuts of the head open from all sides: and water is pressed when you press it with your hand to the inside, and it does not hide from you this: then it must be cut in the middle of the head with three fissures, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tie the fissures with cloths and cotton.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then apply this from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then dissolve the ligament, and care for the wound with compresses, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not dismiss tying the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the weak with all dry food of little moisture, until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to consider where the size of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes there is more in the back, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Then ascend with an incision where you see the abscess and swelling of water, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not cut the artery, and the blood flow occurs, and the weak person dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ On the incision of the arteries that are after the ears.
Caput II.	2nd Head.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrh occurs to someone's eyes or chest, and it is not cured by medical treatment: then the last cure is in that, the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you want to cut them, it should be done so that the weak person's head is relieved.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then tie the weak person's neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is beating.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are locations that are below the ears: and it is rarely hidden, unless in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a hot iron on both: and cut both with a narrow blade, the incision going to the bone: and let it be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you want, insert a narrow blade under the artery, and cut it to the upper part with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the pulse is cut, blood flows out with a pulsating flow, which jumps to the inside frequently.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary to measure from the ear the quantity of space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then indicate with a hot iron and fennel, and scrape up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which should be expelled from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you may expel more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of that according to the amount that appears to you from the weakness and filling of its artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains to the bone from the scab something, then cut that, so that it does not happen hot abscess: then bind the wound with lints from linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has ancient headaches or sharp cataracts due to acidic humors and heat in the temples, or old soda, strong, and similar to those: and he is treated with remedies of cure and not given that: then we have experienced these pains in the extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have said.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in the extraction of them is, that the weak hair which are in the temples be scraped off, and he directs to the artery that appears in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it is shown to you from its pulse, and rarely is hidden except in a few men, or vehemence of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is hidden from you, then he binds his weak head with any of his cloths: then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or steam the place with hot water, until it appears to you with clear appearance.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a small needle, which I have previously formed.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then, remove the skin along with the fascia until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert the hook into it and pull it out towards the top until you remove it from the skin and make it extend through the layers of tissue beneath it from all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If, however, the artery is thin: then cover it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the amount by which their ends extend and contract, so that blood loss does not occur.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut and if it is not severed, the blood will not rise at all.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then wash out the blood with six ounces of water, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary to ligate it in two places with strong double silk thread or with catgut, so that it does not hasten to putrefy before the consolidation of the wound and blood loss occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cauterizing iron and a scalpel until its ends are cut and it remains in the same position of that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to do this unless if the patient is weak and has a fever or a heated constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cauterizing iron is from those things that dry up moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to use a moistening agent.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries, to fill the place with old wheat flour and place some well-made cotton on top of it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the wound is cleaned with dry medicaments that cause flesh to grow and with lotions, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, while you are operating, blood suddenly flows from the artery, then quickly remove it with a cautery, or fill the place with zeugit: and press your hand until the blood stops flowing.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If there is nothing present for you, then place your finger on the spot until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And apply cold water to the spot until the burning stops and it is bandaged as appropriate.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it has a cautery with two knives: and the sharpness of the two knives should be like molten wax.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are as sharp as two knives, both cool quickly and do not cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	However, since there is a little thickness in them, the heat of the fire is held in them, and the flesh is cut quickly: therefore it is better for all work, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And there should be space between the two knives equal to the thickness of a finger, after you mark two spots with the cauterizer: and place both hot ones, until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that it is extended between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not consolidate completely with this cauterizer.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cauterizer.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Concerning the care of the course of sharp, frequent tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are frequent and their course is from the eyes, which are on the outside of the skull above: and nothing is applied to them with medicine, and you see that the face of the sick person is already red, and feels a kind of walking, like the walking of ants: and his eyes are thinned, wet, so that the hairs of his eyebrows are already corroded with corrosion: and his eyelids are hot from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients needed in the cure of these operations, and called it a cure, with a Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	You should command the sick person to shave off the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then you should make three evenly spaced cuts across the forehead according to its length: and let the length of the cut be about two fingers, and let one cut be evenly spaced from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length slightly beyond the shoulder blades, and the third on the other side: and beware of incising the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand away from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the entire length of the incision be the amount of three fingers joined together: and let there be a piece of prepared sponge or dry cloth with which to stop the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert two sharp-pointed needles, whose following form is as follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is on the side of the temple, up to the second incision: and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the flap that is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove that spatula and insert another tool, called a sharp cultello, from one side gently, not sharply from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh with the skin, and its gentle side towards the bone: and push it until it reaches the middle cut: and cut off with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues up to what appears of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle cut up to another cut.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after the blood has flowed out an equal quantity, express the locations from the pieces of clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place linen soaked in old cooked linseed in every wound, and place over them lints moistened with wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And be sure that no abscess of heat occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the bandage, and administer an infusion much with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with basilicon ointment, and with the other things that heal wounds: until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ On the care of sharp tears and catarrh from the inside of the head to the eyes.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When catarrh occurs to someone sharp, sharp, and frequent: and you see his eyes weakened, small, and already weakened is their aspect: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and they fall out from them, and in the deep of the head is sharp pain, hurting, and following sneeze: then take from these accidents that those matters, and catarrh do not come, except from many vents.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And better cure in them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you order the sick to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then cut in that wound one in the middle of the forehead, or another slightly in width, and begin with the wound from the left temple to the right: and it is incision until the bone: and lengthen your hand away from the temple bones, which move at mastication: until when the bone is exposed: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between two lips of the wound with old cooked linen, or with lints of flax.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie above with wool: and drink wool soaked in wine and oil, so that no heat abscess may occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you untie it, and see that the heat abscess is about to diminish: then it is necessary to rub the mouth, until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with a dry diet that causes flesh to grow: as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of pitch: and prepare an ointment from them, and administer it at the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	¶ On the care of that which falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or a stone similar to it, such as iron and copper: or it is a plant, such as beans and peas: or it is a fluid, such as water, and vinegar, and the like: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone, or a kind of stone from those which do not add nor grow in the ear, falls into the ear, expose the ear alone: if then you see the stone, then pour something from broken oil, or sisamin into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer its extraction, and make him sneeze with the conditioned, and close the nose with an onion at the approach of sneezing, after you place in the circumference of the ear fragments of cloth, or wool, and extend the ear to the superior.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Often it exits with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If however it does not exit, then administer its extraction with Gesti, that is, fine pizzarolis: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore it exits with Gesti, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform an extraction of it with a blind hook of fine, slight duplication.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not exit through that, then make a cannula from air, and insert the end of the cannula into the ear canal a lot, and apply oil with softened wax around the cannula to prevent air from entering except through the cannula: then extract with your strong attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For it often exits with what we mentioned.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not exit in this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from usco, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the radius after you have put on it a cloth properly positioned: then insert it into the ear canal when you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not exit with all that we mentioned, then hasten to cut it before an abscess or hot fever, or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of incision is, that a weak phlebotomist should be placed in the first place in the cephalic vein: and extract it from him according to the measure of its power.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear towards the upper part, and find a small incision in the root of the ear at the fatty part of him in the depressed place: and let the incision be in the shape of a crescent moon until you reach the stone: then remove it with what is possible from your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew the incision from your hour with speed and care until he is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If the thing falling into the ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell: then perform an extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it still does not obey you at the end, then take a thin, delicate spatula in this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the separation of that kind from the grains that fall into the ear, and do not do it when you think that that grain is already moistened by the steam of the ear, until you place many fragments: then remove them with hooks, or with a fine instrument, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction is alleviated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But in the water that enters the ear, it is necessary to use an infirm sneezing with the first condition: and now it has filled its own ear with some cooked old [grain]: and it is lying on that ear, in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it exits through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of the finger, thin, soft, and heat them with fire for a while, and let the infirm one insert one of them into the hole of its ear: and salt on one of his feet from that part, and strike with another stone on the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not therefore cease doing it with the stone and the stone, until all the water exits.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water exits thus, that you take from the pus, or from the dung one, and insert its end one into the ear: and heat its other end with fire, until it is burned much of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the dung another one, and do it many times, until all the water exits: and remove it with a tube according to that which was prescribed in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of the animal entering into it, if it is small of body, such as a flea, and similar to that, take care of him as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	If it is a large body part that is visible to the senses, then administer its extraction with forceps and hooks, and its removal is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	However, when you extract the worms generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we mentioned in division and in the treatment of distillations, and your care does not bring about cure: then you should look at the ear in the sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something appears there from the worms, then remove it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there from the worms, then take a cannula, whose form is narrow below and wide above: and insert its fine tip into the ear according to the amount that the weak person can tolerate: then suck with it strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to the end, then wrap a woolen cloth around the cannula with clay, as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with that, then administer the distillations which the ancients have been acquainted with in the puncturing of worms: and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be what you pour out oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver, or from brass, below narrow, in which there is a small hole, above wide.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore let the thing that is in the hollow of the cannula be made from brass properly.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a radium, and wrap it in a proper fold of cotton at the end of it: then project oil, or suck, or whatever you want from these medicines into the cannula: and let it be in the ear: then insert the radium with the cotton above, and press it with your tempered hand compression until the oil is forced into the hollow of the ear, and the weak person feels it inside: and that which is poured into the ear should already be warmed with a little fire: and beware that there is nothing that is distilled into it very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Translation: On the Care of Accidental Burns from Gold.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes, infants occasionally emerge from their mother's wombs without being pierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that burning occurs in the ear canal from a wound, or from flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this burning sometimes occurs in the deep canal of the ear, which does not reach sight: and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the canal, and reaches sight.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, that which happens in the deep ear, and which does not include sight, is difficult to cure in many positions.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows sight, it is necessary to place the ear of the sick person in the sun, and look at it: then if you see the burning appearing, open it with a thin, subtle probe, whose form is as follows: its end is small, and has a small width; and the rest of the probe is flat on both sides: so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the burning is born from flesh in the ear canal: then hold it with a thin, sharp instrument, and cut it with great force, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the burning is in the deep ear: then take a thin, sharp, and heated probe with a little fire: then put it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you feel the burning with that which the sick person has, if he experiences great difficulty in hearing, try to open it with force: and beware, do not wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear a liniment according to the size of the canal, which you have unfolded in Egyptian oil: make it for several days, until you are secure about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Take linseed and infuse it in rosewater, then sprinkle powdered zegi on it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see an ear already suppurating, then it is necessary to remove the linseed, and let it be placed with another linen cloth that has been rolled in oil made with rosewater, until the boil becomes hot: then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if blood is flowing, then immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water, and place it on the ear: and use the rest of the treatment that stops the predicted bleeding in the aforementioned treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the care of Althea's eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Althelia which occur in the eyelids of the eye, sometimes are moist and sometimes are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary to hold them with tweezers: or with an uncinus, and cut them off from their roots with a lancet.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place powdered zegi on the affected areas.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lenticular cauterizer.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterize them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when there remains something from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots burn and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the care of Granatum's eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often something occurs in the eyelids that resembles the strength and hardness of Granatum, and because of this it is called Grando: and it is an accumulation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation for these is thus: consider if it is a frost (a cold sore) proceeding from that which appears from the eyelid, and moves to all parts, and its matter is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore above it a fissure of width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from all parts with facility, until it subsides.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a splint, and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if the cutting off of it is not prepared for you, unless when you penetrate the eyelid with an incision a little, then it harms the weak one in some place.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the fissure is large: then gather it with a suture: and care for it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For an ointment restores it, and flesh it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the frost is declining towards the interior of the ear, turned away from the inner surface, then turn the eyelid, and suspend the frost with a splint: besides which you need an incision, and press it from all parts.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is lengthened by an incision, it does not harm it in some place.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the frost, with salted water: and care for the place with that which fleshes it, until the weak one heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	¶ About the care of Axiromath for the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fat which is generated in the tunics of the upper eyelid: and much indeed happens to it in children: and it blurs their eyes, and cataracts happen to them in the morning, and they cannot see the light of the sun, because their tears rush to them, and on account of this you see them lying on their faces always, and they sleep on them, and their eyelids are under wet arches, which inflation has already covered: and the eminence of Axirnath appears to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method of operation is for the sick person to place his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare a poultice in it, and make from it a circle of the size that contains the Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him on it, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with a thin blade making incisions along the width, and let there not be an incision larger than that which is made in bloodletting in the depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary to make an incision in the whole skin, until you reach the Axirnath, for the Axirnath proceeds from the incision in many ways according to the shape of a white fat fragment.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract it therefore with the cloth that you have soaked between your fingers to the outsides: and you turn your hand to the right and left, until it is spread: and beware, do not add in the incision, so that the blade does not reach with the thin blade to the eye, and you wound him.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you will add a little with ease into the incision, until the Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the place, and bind him with poultices.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some men who sprinkle salt on it, and place it in the hollow of the incision, so that what remains of that moisture is melted.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if an abscess occurs in the place of heat, then care for him with sedative plasters, until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the ways of Ataxmir's eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft and the eye waters excessively, causing it to water incorrectly.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional eyelashes grow in the eyelids beyond their usual course and become ingrown: then they harm the eye, causing various afflictions such as frequent tears, eyelid softening, and sclera, leading to the cause of eye destruction.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir indeed cures the eye in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as previously mentioned in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or by incision and sutures.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by cannulas, as I will say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is turned, then it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not, then insert the needle into the one where the hair is from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with thread from above, and be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and pull the thread to the upper part with the eyelid, and turn it with a spoon.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a thin probe entering from the larger lacrimal duct up to the smaller lacrimal duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place a small amount of charcoal or cloth under the eyelid: then mark on the eyelid with cauterizing iron, which is like the shape of myrtle leaves.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary to make the figure according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid, since this varies among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For some, it is necessary for the figure to extend beyond the eyelid due to the large quantity that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then, with the spatula, draw a line above two lines that you have marked, and begin from the larger lacrimal to the smaller one, and let there be a fissure near the natural hairs, like the size of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape off the entire scale.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather the two lips with a suture, with a needle and fine thread of wool: and wipe off the blood, and make that which is superfluous from the threads over the two eyebrows stick to it, with some things that prevent it from unraveling, if you wish to do so; and if not, you will not care.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and thread for three days or four, and then take care of it afterwards.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without a suture, and take care of it with that which dries and constricts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is elevated at the sign of the wound and its gathering, but it will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	The ancients taught this method of healing Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is anxiety over the weak one, and it is from good surgery, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is also taught by Ataxmir: and it is to make signs on the eyelid in the form of a figure, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then elevate the eyelid with three separate or gathered hooks, according to this following form, and then cut off what is superfluous with small forceps, according to this form, with equality of incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and it does not fit: then take a needle with thread, and insert it in the middle of the shape: and insert another thread near the tear duct, larger, and another thread near the tear duct, smaller: and gather the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand evenly by elevation: and lift the skin over which is marked with ink, as we have told you.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather two wound lips with suture: and care for it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if an abscess occurs near your incision, or your wound: then soothe the abscess with charcoal, and these similar things, from ointments that settle.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelids also, that their hairs turn.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore you should use what we said in the incision: but the suture on both is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	¶ On the care of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	AND IT IS, that you turn the eyelid, and tear the wound that is inside, as I have told you.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two splints, or two thin pieces of wood: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width is less than the width of a finger: and you have already cut on the extremities of each from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each of them with thinness on top of what exceeds from the eyelid of the eye, and tie two splints from both sides with a strong suture, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin tight will die, and blacken, and rot, until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it delays, then cut it with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it is consolidated, raise the eyelid: and do not prick the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two needles that you will make according to this figure and quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	About raising hairs that prick in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in that is, to take a thin needle and insert it into the hair with a fine silk thread, gentle.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends and tie both knots with a very fine silk thread: and the length of the threads should be one finger.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then compose another fine silk thread under it in a short space, and tie the ends of it if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the weak head on your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation can be shown: because it is a delicate or small operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the silk thread into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate into the eyelid quickly, until you pull it out from above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up to above the silk thread: and insert that hair into the silk thread: if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it, until the hair comes out with the silk thread into the eyelid with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the silk thread is pulled, and the hair does not come out with it: pull the silk thread downwards, with the thread that you composed in it, until the silk thread comes out from the upper opening, and see it with the vision of the eye: then pull the silk thread and the thread: and remove both, and close the eye: and let it be closed for two days, or three, until the hair sticks in its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then associate it with a longer hair from natural hairs, and lift it with that: or let it be, until it lengthens after some time, and then lift it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of Alexander that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alexander's eye occurs, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alexander's eye is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore it is accidental from the consolidation of a wound, or cutting, or cauterization, and similar to those.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation in it is, that you find that consolidation, and that you separate its lips, and that you put in it what is between them linen from linen, and bandage it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary that you use in the cure of things that dry and contract: for if you do this, Alexander's eye returns worse than it was: rather use in it those things that soften, such as fenugreek: and rub with water in which althea has been cooked, seed linen: and ointment dyaquilon, which has been melted with some oil: and wrap with it linen, and care for it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasure of cure is that you try with every skill, that it not consolidate, according to the form that it was in first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we said is indeed only some correction of Alexander, so that it does not return to the form of the place according to what it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the care of Alexander that occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkle or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This is what is done below, which is truly called Albucasis.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one is made from a wound, or a tear, or a cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the method of operation in it is, that you take a needle, in which there is a double thread, and you dip it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut it with a broad-bladed knife.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the figure of the eyelid returns according to what is proper, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the radium, and put it in the tear, and turn with it the eyelid: and make two tears on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two tears be from two corners of the incision, until they meet and form an angle from them: until when they gather together, this figure is made, and it is the Greek letter laud.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount, which is the sharp side of its width below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separate parts: sew it with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we said, with softening medicines, and lotions, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Albucasis happens from a tear and a stitch, or a cauterization: then it is necessary to make the tear flat under the eyelashes, even as it preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with a ligature, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of the speech about the care of Albucasis, whether it is above or below, is that he should operate on it according to the operation prepared from the form of Albucasis.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it is of many diverse forms: and the skilled artisan prepares his skill with whatever way is possible for him, until he makes the figure return to the natural form, or near to it, and himself the infirm one, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid with the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid is consolidated with the whites of the eye, and prevents it from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore you must insert the end of the ray under the eyelid, and raise it up: or extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a thin, small knife, which is not with the sharpness of the knives, but is blunt for a little: so that the infirm one may not be disturbed by the operation, and the knife may not injure the eye with its sharpness: and your incision will be as if you are scraping off that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the whole adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour in the eye salt water, with water to clean it: or sprinkle in it from a sponge made of zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a ligature line: and place on the eye a soaked cloth with egg white: and after three days use a sponge, and with firm things, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the Incision of the Claw and Prominence of Flesh for Tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the claw is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous: and it is similar to a hard, thin string.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture of white: which when it touches the iron flame, or you try to take it with the hook, it is cut off, and does not stick on it the hook.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin, except from the larger tear-duct, until it gradually reaches, so that it covers the sight, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation in its incision is: that you put your weak head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and raise the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the claw with a hook of few multiplications, and extend it to the upper parts.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle, and insert in it a needle from the needles of horses, or oxen, or goose: and let it be strong, and double the tip of the needle a little, and fix it in the middle of the claw: and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the claw with thread, and extend it to the upper parts: and scrape off the side of the claw that follows the pupil, as if you hold it with the thread until its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.
