Then cut off the remainder at the root of the tear-duct with a thin, sharp knife, or with small forceps: and let go the natural flesh of the tear-duct, so that it may not happen from its incision that the course of tears is constant.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the claw is extended with a hook alone: or with thread, as we said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then, he shaves with a mild exfoliant, whose shape is as follows.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware, lest the exfoliant touch the horn-like skin of the eyelid and cause a tear, and perforate the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, put something salty and crushed into the eye, or made from sieving sewage, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary until he is healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the eyelid is not nervous, and you cannot insert an awl into it nor fix a hook in it, then this kind of eyelid is often treated with medicines and healed as I have described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you want to cut it, then open the eye of the sick person, and take a thin, mild, weak exfoliant, according to this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And shave the eyelid from above with the same thinness.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is rarefied and broken, and you press on it, then pour from your hourglass into the eye a liquid made from sieving sewage, or from sieving red, or crushed salt: and keep the eye closed until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation over it, until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless the opposite is true in your eye, a hot abscess: then leave it, and care for the abscess until it is healed.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation over it with the razor, until it is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	However, if the elevation of the eyelid causes harm to the eye with great injury, it is suspended with a hook, and cut from that part: and do not complete the incision, so that the course of tears does not occur.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then, pour some rubbed red stone, or that made from azurite, into the lachrymal until it is healed.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Of the incision of Al-Guardian, and flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes flesh is born in certain human eyes, composed or placed with red, until it covers the pupil, or approaches, or stretches over the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids to the outside: and it resembles a balmrose rose.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation in it is also that he places his weak head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and gather all that flesh with the appropriate hooks to that: and hold it with a wrench, or a hook.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh in the first place, until it is all of his with the incisor.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And beware of the eye, so that you do not wound it in the operation: and your incision is what you cut it with, or with a small spatula, which we mentioned in the incision of the hoof: or with small forceps, with which it is gathered, according to the form it will have after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	Then when your incision is completed, and the whole Al-Guardian is removed, then fill the eye with crushed salt: or pour in it red powder, and similar to it from corrosive medicines: and place on the deformed eye a bandage with egg white: so that it is secured from hot suppuration.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If there remains any of Al-Guardian, and hot blood rules you, and you fear hot suppuration: then let go the eye, and care for it with that which calms the suppuration.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it with the operation, until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Similarly, perform with added flesh that occurs in the eye from this type.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary to operate on all weak eyes from the natural or accidental way with iron: and you should not put your hand into any of these operations until you see that that member can tolerate that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	¶ On collecting sebel from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebel are red veins that cover the eye and prevent their operation: and they weaken the eye with the length of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore it is necessary for you to first consider whether the eye in which there is sebel is strong, and there is no other illness in it except sebel: then collect sebel from that eye.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is, that you command the weak one, that he put his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with a needle one or two according to your prudence: and the needle should be thin for the formation of the stitches, in this form, or there are two needles gradually in one body, in this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect those veins with thin forceps with thinness, and remove the blood hour by hour, until you see that those veins are removed from the eye, and they dissolve: and beware not to injure the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And your operation should be in midday before the sun, and you should be strong in your operation greatly: so that you do not cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have filled it, then pour green or red wine into the eye: so that its sharpness corrodes what remains from sebel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to collect all of it in that hour, then apply plasters to the eye with what soothes the pain of the eye: and let him rest for several days until the pain settles: and secure it from hot abscess: and then repeat on it according to the same method, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of Aries (the nose) to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The doctors call Aries (the nose) a fistula, which they cure with a cauterizer or with a sharp burning medicine, according to what was previously reported about it.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it is not cured, then there is no skill in it: unless you find the abscess at its birthplace and remove all the moisture and pus that is in it, until the nose is cleaned.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore the nose is cleaned and you see decay or discoloration in it, then shave it with an instrument of this form.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the rough head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron and its head round like an azir, which is dotted with a file or with a fine puncturing of the aliskilfer: and put it on top of the rotten bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then turn it between your fingers and press your hand on it for a while until you know that that decay is now scraped off: and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with dry hemostatic medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place consolidates and flesh grows in it and the course of pus is cut off: and it remains for forty days and does not renew, and does not form an abscess, and nothing bad happens to it: then you know that it is healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no skill in it: unless you reduce the fistula to the nostril opening, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is, that you scrape off the bone second with iron or with a sharp medicine: and when the bone is detected, then take the drill according to this form, its end is iron, triangular: and the wood of it is a flattened pyramid until its end, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it on the eye itself: and let it be near the lacrimal point: and lengthen your hand away from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the trephine until it enters the eye, and feels it to be weak: by which, as it finds the wind coming out of it, when it holds its hand on its nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with astringent healing medicines, as I taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore the flesh is born and the place hardens: then the matter that flowed to the outsides returns to the nose: it is therefore lighter on the weak.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	¶ On the Reduction of the Prominence of the Eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes with its whole, and no harm occurs in the sight, nor diminution: then it is necessary to dissolve the weak: then you must bleed him: afterwards place windy ones in the temples without scarification, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place a liniment on the eye which is made of acacia, and aloe, and olibanum, and sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye above with a plaster with many pledgets.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of the pledgets is: that you take soft cloths, many, and double each cloth on top of four: make many from them: then place them one over another according to the amount that the eye needs: then bind them with a hard cloth and a strong binding.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat windy ones with suction without scarification.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the windy ones, and let the eye loose day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the bandage again becomes soft, then it is necessary to bind much: then remove the bandage day and night, as we said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see the eye about to return to its original position, it is good; but if not, then repeat the ointment, bandages, and splints, and the windy [treatment], until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Of incision of the eye's membrane.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a tear occurs in the eye's membrane, it then protrudes and extends outside the eyelids like a grain of sand, and defaces the form of man due to this, and you wish to cut it: then the operation on him is as follows: and it is, that you insert a needle into the root of the eye from the lower part to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle where there is a double thread from the part of the lacrimal gland, and make it penetrate: and release the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of the double thread, and tie it with that part of the eye in the circumference of the needle: and tie it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, and place a soaked wool above the eye on the white of the eye: and release him, until the thread falls with the eye.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with him, that it strengthens him, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the eye is tied up with a bandage from all parts with a circle of cloth, until the eye gains a great elevation.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a thin lancet, which reaches to the depth of the eye, and cleanses the humidity of the white of the eye, and the eye descends, and goes in immediately: then tie him, until he heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	Of the treatment of almonds.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This illness which is called almond, is not, unless it is pus, which gathers in the eye, similar to water descending, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method of operation in this is, that you make the disabled person sit on a prepared seat, or a straight one.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in your hands from the two sides, and move it, until you see health reach the lower parts of your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then shape it, and let it not descend, and let the light be completed: and the disabled person will see as he used to: and if it does not descend lower, you will know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the preparation of the descent of health does not come with what we said, then make the disabled person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a thin lancet, and prick with it above the corneal skin a little at the continuation of the joined part with the corneal tunic to the corona, until the pus comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When therefore it comes out, then pour warm water into the eye in which you mixed honey: or water in which you already boiled fennel and honey: then let it be treated with the rest of the cure, until he is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	¶ On the care of water that descends into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	Now we have already mentioned the appearance of water in division, and what is appropriate for cutting with speech declaring and explaining, then take that same one according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then therefore you must make the disabled person sit between your hands squarely, opposite the light, near the sun: and bind the healthy eye, and pull it very tight: then open the eyelid of his eye with your right hand, if the eye in which is water is the left: or with your left hand, if the eye is right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take with your right hand alumgum, if the eye is left: or with your left hand, if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the needle near the corona at the thickened part of the radius appearing in the whiteness of the eye's lachrymal: then push the needle with force, and you will turn it back with your hand until it penetrates into the sclera of the eye: and feel that the needle has already reached the empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it should be the measure of the path of the needle to the depth, the measure of the space that is from the pupil to the end of the darkness: and it is the corona of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see them in the pupil itself of the eye, because of the clarity of the tunic of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the needle until it reaches the place where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it downward, one after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If therefore the water comes down immediately, then the sick person sees that above which he opens his eye immediately, and the needle in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If therefore the water comes down, then lay it down in the second place, except that the needle goes out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When therefore it sticks, and does not rise: then take out the needle with ease: and you will turn back your hand gradually.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something clear from the salt of jewelry in water: and wash with it the eye inside.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place outside the eye all the bandage, or woven cloth dyed with rose oil, and with sclera of eye: and tie it with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are of our time, place on him ground almond with sclera of eye.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the needle does not obey you for entering into the eye because of its hardness, since it is from a person whose eye is very hard: then you must take a small tool, which is called Alberid, of which this is the form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore, connect it with that joint only and do not insert your hand through the opening: and it is only so that you may make a way to the delicate spot of the womb.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the sponge, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your work, prepare for him a decently made bed of rest, in which he may lie on his back in a dark room: and let him be prevented from all movements, and from coughing: and place his food, that which nature leni
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage be according to its condition up to the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then dissolve it in that dark room, and examine his sight: and make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the bandage up to the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary to do it at the hour of cure, or immediately after incision: but rather that others do it: because water ascends quickly through a strong gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if it happens to be a hot abscess: then it is necessary to dissolve the eye before the seventh: and correct it with that which sedates the abscess, until it is sedated: then complete his sight, and place on his face an oral remedy by which his sight is regulated for several days, while he is still in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then he should go out of the house gradually, and return to his usual activities.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And you should know that in the case of a student, vision is not excused from zaltea: for then he dares to perform operations.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed, one of those who are from Alayrach has come to us, who said that it happened in Alayrach that a man was perforated, through which water is drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	I have not seen anyone in our land who has done this: nor have I read it in any book of the ancients; and it is possible that it may be new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of species from which it stands above those who do not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	They should be made of air properly: and their ends should be with the same subtlety of a triangle, and a sharp end.
Formae magda.	Forms of the great.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of flesh born in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes flesh is born in the nose that is added with various kinds, of which there is something that resembles a scorpion of many feet: and from this is cancerous flesh, stone-like, of a dark color: and from this is the flesh that is soft, not of a dark color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In that therefore which is from those flesh that is soft, not deceitful, nor cancerous, it is necessary for you to do this: sit the weak in your hands opposite to the sun, and open his nose, and thrust a hook into those flesh: then draw them out to the exterior, and cut what you have grasped from them with a thin sharp knife on one side, until you know that all the flesh is removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If something remained from which its removal is not possible: then shave it with one of the tools with facility, until there is nothing remaining from it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If however blood dominates you, or hot abscess happens to you: then apply to him what is necessary: or it is from malignant abscesses, then hasten cauterizing him, until the blood is cut off, and all the flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then throw into the nose after incision vinegar, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose opens and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then you will know that he is already healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If, however, the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you will know that there is flesh born within him in the upper parts of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then you should insert a string with some bulk and many knots in it: and place between each knot the quantity of a finger or less: and make him bend his weak hand, so that he sends one end of the string into his nose with a probe, or with whatever is possible for him to do after he has made it similar to an azzer: and draw out his smell, until it reaches the throat, and comes out over his neck.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And they often do something similar to this of Attoumi boys in school: and it is an easy thing for him who wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the string: one that comes out over the nose, and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then the flesh with the knots that are on the string should be cut off.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is now with the knots of the string.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the string: and put it into his nose after washing away the blood: with the linen that you soaked in the Egyptian ointment: do this for three days, or more, until the ointment corrodes all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put at the end of the matter into his nose a lead tube, for several days, until he is healed.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however he needs the cure that will dry it out, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	To perform the extraction of a tooth, when drops of olive oil and other medicines are applied to the nose, do this with silver or bronze: it should be similar to a small lamp, open like a shell: and its channel likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for tooth extraction should be full, empty: with a handle at its end, with which you hold it, when you heat oil or whatever you wish to extract from flexible substances and things.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the care of the nose.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Often a wart grows at the end of the nose, and it becomes prominent and increases with the days, until it becomes disgusting in appearance.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of this, it is necessary to cut off that at the beginning of its appearance, and uproot all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place on the spot, or a cauterizing iron, or a burning medicine that remains in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If therefore the cutting of it is delayed until it becomes prominent, then consider if it is stone-like, hard, dark in color, few sensations: then do not touch it with iron: because it is an abscess that is cancerous.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For often I have seen people who cut into an abscess, and harm came to them from it great evil upon him who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the abscess is gentle to touch, not dark in color, and you see that cutting it all is possible, then evacuate the weak one, and cut it without fear, without pity: and care for the spot with what dries and contracts, until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Regarding the closure of the nose, lips, and ear:
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You should know that when there is a disruption of continuity in one of these cartilages, it does not greatly benefit from an operation, except in certain people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when something happens to someone from this, you should consider whether it is a recent wound with its own blood: and then gather the edges of the wound with sutures, and then care for it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the disruption of continuity has already separated the lips, and each part is healthy: then you should scrape off all the part from its apparent skin, until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then gather two lips with sutures, and tie them, and powder the dragon's blood on top of the blood, and ground frankincense: and place above the powders a fragment of the plaster diafinicon, and some other of the consolidating plasters: and leave it tied for two days, or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then dissolve it, and change the medication: and leave it until the sutures come off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suture is to gather the disruption of continuity, or with a needle, as we have told you about the suture of the stomach: or gather it with thread, as I have taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	Regarding the removal of warts on the lips:
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people indeed have warts often on the inner parts of their lips, which are hard and similar to grains of herbs: and some of them are smaller, and some larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore you should turn the lip, and scrape over every wart of it, and hang it with a needle, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the space after incision with zeig crushed until the blood stops flowing.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then apply a mixture of vinegar and honey to the wound, and dress it with a stiptic substance until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	About making an incision on the flesh of the thigh over the knee joint.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Often flesh grows on the knee joint, which the ancients called abulus.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore, you should hang it with a hook: or hold it with forceps, and cut it at its root, and let the pus run out, or blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on the wound zeig crushed, or other stiptic and dry powders.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If that flesh returns after healing, for it often returns, then cut it again and cauterize it: for it does not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	About the reason of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes they gather on the surfaces of teeth from the inner and outer parts, and between the jaws rough, foul, and sometimes turn yellow and green, until that corruption reaches the jaw, and the teeth become foul through it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore, you should make the weak one sit between your hands, and his head in your lap, and shave the molar and tooth, in which the roughness and sand-like substance appear to you: until nothing remains from them, and similarly do with blackness, greenness, and yellowness, and other things until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore that which is in them from the beginning of reason is removed, it is good: and if not, then repeat the razor on them on another day, second, and third, until you reach the end of your desire in it.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that the tooth requires razors of various shapes and many forms: according to how it is prepared for your operation; because the razor with which it is removed from the lower part of the tooth is different from the razor with which it is removed between the teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And those forms of razors should be prepared by you, as you see them.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the extraction of tooth pain.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You should cure the tooth from its pain with all your skill, and slowly remove it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For it does not fit its place when it is removed: because it is a subtle substance; until there is no excuse for its removal, then when the sick person must remove it himself, to strengthen and be certain about the tooth that causes pain.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For often the pain deceives the sick person, and he thinks that it is in the tooth and removes it; then the pain does not go away, until the weak tooth is removed.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen this from the operation of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When therefore the tooth that causes pain is removed by himself, then you should scarify around the tooth with a small knife, in which there is something of its virtue, until the gum is separated from all parts; then move it with your fingers, or with fine forceps gradually, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps in that location with good position, and the head of the sick person between your knees; which you have already held well, so that it does not move: then pull the tooth according to its straightness, so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If therefore it does not come out, then take one of those instruments, and insert it under it from all parts with ease, and try its movement, as you did in the first place.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded, then it is necessary to fill the hole with a cloth: and to tie it with the thin end of a finger, so that it does not break during your constriction with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary to carefully perform the incision around the jaw from all sides, much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And keep your strength, so that you do not break it, and its part remains, and it returns to the weaker one from that greater malice which is its first pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware, so that you do not do what ignorant phlebotomists do in their haste, and the audacity of them over its extraction, besides which they administer what we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For they often cause great harm to people, whose difficulties are such that they break them, and all their roots remain, or some of them: or that they extract it with certain jawbones: as we have often testified.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it should be covered after its extraction with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	Which if there is bleeding from the places (for it often happens), then wipe some zege with it, and fill it with it: and if not, cauterize it if it does not give you zege.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forms of the fine forceps by which the tooth is moved in the first place, should be long at the ends, short in the handle, thick, so that they do not double when pressed on the tooth: they should be like the thick handles, until when you tie with them, they do not bite themselves, nor double: short at the ends, and made from iron, or from a well-made file, straight ends: and in their ends there should be teeth, some of which enter into certain ones, and tie with a proper constriction, strong.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes such ends occur like the form of a bird's beak, which is called a stork, and they are strong in their contraction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the Removal of Teeth, and Extraction of the Jawbones' Bicuspids.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When there remains at the removal of a tooth that is broken, then it is necessary to place butter on the spot for one or two days, until the spot becomes soft: then introduce into it algasti, or forceps: whose ends resemble the beak of a bird, which is called a stork.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	However, this is the form of forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Let their ends be made like a file inside: or like an algasti.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If therefore it does not obey you with these forceps, then it is necessary to make an incision on the root, and tear away all the flesh, and introduce the instrument called a small pincer, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let it be short in its end, rather thick: and not wetted, so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root exits through that, it is good: and if not, you must wriggle with these other instruments whose forms are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The form of the first triangular end, in which there is a certain thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The form of the thin triangular end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	Also wriggle with this instrument having two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools that preceded in the ratio of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also wriggle with this instrument that resembles a large hook, whose form is this: a twisted triangular end, in which there is a certain thickness, so that it does not break: and it is not wetted.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many dental instruments: and similarly, the other tools are not counted, and a wise craftsman, skilled in his art, has found for himself alone the tool, according to what signifies to him the operation and the very pains themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For since from the pains to which they did not say the tool, because of the diversity of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if the jawbone is broken from the jaw, or from other bones of the mouth, or rots: then to examine above it in its place with that which suits him from the tools and forceps that I said in extraction of root, and to heal with the gesture whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be something of bulk gradually, so that it is tied or held with the jawbone, and does not flee and run away, until the jawbone comes out: and restore the place with suitable medicines to that.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a small rot in the bone, then shave it from its own rot, and heal it, until it is healed.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of the cutting of teeth projecting above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When the teeth do not project above others according to their natural course, it becomes disfigured by that form: and especially when it happens in women, and girls, that is, those who are marriageable.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore you must consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if the tooth is born after another tooth, and does not fit, or is possible to cut it, nor to shave it: then eradicate it: and if it is connected with another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, whose form is this.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is similar to a small beak, and is made of iron, with very sharp extremities.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be where you incise on many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that another is not moved by the teeth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is prominent and exposed, then it is filed with its own file, which has this form.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let the whole be of india, and its handle is made of fine points, like a needle with which needles are made: with which tooth is filed gradually on many days with ease, so that the tooth is not moved, and it falls: then smooth it, at the end shave it with some razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	But if it is a tooth from which part breaks off and hurts the tongue: then it is necessary that the file even that, until the roughness of that fracture is removed, and it is equal: and it is flattened, and it does not hurt the tongue, nor corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	¶ On the filing of teeth with gold files.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens to the front teeth that they are shaken and moved by a blow, or by chance: and the weak one cannot string over that which he eats so that it does not fall: and you have treated them with hemostatic remedies, and the cure did not improve: then the skill in them is, that they are strung with gold wire: because silver becomes green, and putrefies after days: but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of medium thinness and thickness according to the amount that it takes between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the shape of the filing is indeed, that you take the wire, and insert a double of it between two healthy teeth: then weave with the two ends of the wire between the moving teeth, whether one is, or more, until you reach with the net to the tooth of the other part.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the texturing until you reach the part where you started: and tie your hand with skill and wisdom, until it is completely removed: and your binding should be like tying a thread, at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut the excess ends of the thread with forceps: and gather both, and fold them with a hook: and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moving tooth, so that it does not hurt the tongue: then let it be released as tightly as possible while it remains.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it is loosened or cut, tie them with another thread, and it will stand with it in this way for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of the teeth, and the shape of the binding of two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two return to their places after the fall of both, and they are retained as we have said, and remain: and this is not done by anyone other than a skilled and experienced craftsman.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes something is taken from the cow's bones: and it is made into the shape of a tooth, and it is placed in the place from which the tooth is protected and tied, as we have said: and it remains, and it is served with it for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	¶ About the cutting of the ligament that happens under the tongue, and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that happens under the tongue is either natural, with which man is born, or accidental, from a wound that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in it is, that you open the mouth of the sick person in his neck, and raise his tongue: then cut that nervous ligament in width, until the tongue is released from its binding.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something hard and knotted in it, and it is due to the consolidation of the wound: then push a hook into it, and cut it across its width until you sever the ligament, and the knotting will be dissolved.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And beware, lest there be a deep cut into the flesh, and you sever an artery there, and there is a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then apply a compress to the wound with rosewater, or with vinegar, or with cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place a linen rag under the tongue, which the weak person should hold all night: so that it does not consolidate again in the second day.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if there is a flow of blood, then apply charcoal powder on the place.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the blood gushes out, then cauterize the place with a blunt cauterizer, which is suitable for that: and then care for it along with the other cure, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	About the extraction of a ranula that is formed under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes an abscess occurs under the tongue that resembles a small ranula, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function: and perhaps it becomes so large, that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation in it is, to open the mouth of the weak person in front of the sun: and examine the abscess.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see it is of a dark or black color, hard, and which the weak person does not feel: then do not touch it, because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it is inclined towards whiteness, in which there is moisture, then push a hook into it, and cut it with a thin saw, and free it from all parts.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If the blood insists on you during your surgical operation, then place some crushed zeigum on it until the blood is removed: then return to your operation until you have extracted it with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then bandage it with vinegar and salt: and take care of the rest of its cure according to what is suitable for that, until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the cure of two abscesses in the tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes abscesses occur between the throat and the glands, which resemble those of the thyroid, which occur deformed: and they are called two tonsils: which when you care for with what we said in division, and do not heal, then consider.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If therefore it is a hard abscess, brownish color, little pain: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is reddish color, and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather leave it until it ripens.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you will pierce it: or it will burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white color, round, and its root is thin: then it must be pierced.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is, that you consider before your operation, if the abscess of it has quieted by warm completion, or it is diminished by some reduction: then therefore make the sick one sit in front of the sun, and his head in your lap: and open his mouth, and let him receive a servant between his hands, and press his tongue inferior with an instrument, whose this is form.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or of brass, that it is thin like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	Then when you press it with him the tongue, and the abscess appears to you, and falls on it your sight: then take a hook, and fix it in the tonsil, and extract it as much as you can outside, except that you pull with it some from the clothes.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument of this form, which follows:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles forceps: however, its extremities should be cared for, so that the opening of each is directly opposite and sharp: therefore, ensure that it is made of iron or enameled.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	But if this instrument is not present, then cut it with a spatula of this form:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be sharp on one side, not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after cutting one almond, cut the other according to this same form of cutting.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after cutting, make the sick person gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if blood flow occurs to him, gargle with water in which boiled are the shells of almonds: or myrtle leaves, and similar to those from stiptics, until the blood flow stops: then care for it, until it is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes abscesses arise in the throat other than the two almonds.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Then cut them according to what I said in the cutting of the two almonds equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I myself have already treated a woman with an abscess, which was born between her throat, which was pulling to the esophagus, few senses, which had almost closed her throat: and the woman was breathing through a tightly closed mouth, and had already prevented her from eating and drinking water: and she had already reached death, if it had remained for one day, or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had risen so much that it had emitted two branches, until they came out over two holes of the nose.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I therefore acted quickly and fixed one of their claws.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and from it I extracted a large portion.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off, where it was grasped from the nostril opening.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did the same to the other one that protruded from the nostril opening.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened its mouth, and pressed its tongue: and afterwards I fixed a claw in the pus: then I cut out part of it, and only a few drops of blood flowed from it: thus the throat of the woman was healed, and she immediately began to drink water, and then took food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not stop cutting out from that pus many times over a long period of time: and the abscess succeeded in the place where I was cutting, until it was prolonged too much and with it that one.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore I devised, and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So it stood by the addition: then I walked away from that side, and I did not know what God did with her after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	About cutting out abscesses in the gums.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the catarrh descends to the gum, and becomes an abscess, and is long: then it is called a perpendicular one: and if it is in the lower part thick, round, then it is called a wound.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with what we said in division, and does not require cure: and you see that the abscess has become quiet from her, and is thin: then it is necessary to cut it out.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is collected from it is round, and there is no length to it, and it is bloody, or of a yellowish-brown color, or black, and there is no sense in it: then it is necessary to make an incision into its opening.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	In that case, there is fear of the weak one.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the method that I mentioned from its whiteness and length, you should make the weak one sit facing the sun: and press its tongue with the instrument of which I previously spoke, then fasten a hook in the throat, and pull it downwards: and cut it with one of the two instruments that I mentioned in the incision of two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut from it, except that which is added above the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from it more, you injure voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use what we mentioned in the incision of two tonsils: and care for it, until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the weak one is frightened by the incision, then you must use your skill in its cauterization without fear and cowardice.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterization in it is not, except with sharp water: and it is, that you place the head of the weak one in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press its tongue with the instrument that we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water that I told you in the chapter of cauterization, and mix it with hot ash, and place it not thick nor subtle, and fill the hollow of this instrument, whose form is this.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let its end be in which the medicine is placed, concavity, as the concavity of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on the very same hook: and the weak one should be lying on its side, so that salt comes out of its mouth from the internal medicine, so that nothing descends from it to the throat of itself and injures it.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you apply it to the first part of the wound, in the amount of half an hour, until you see that it is already dissipated and soothed by the medicine's bite.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a probe, and wrap it around the tip of the finger, and pour the probe with the medicine, and insert the finger with the probe into a tube from above, until the probe sticks to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you achieve what you want from the cauterization of the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it go: for it indeed dries up and falls off after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	But if you need to reapply the medicine, apply it again: and after cauterization, clean around the wound with a probe immersed in butter, and wipe with what is in its surroundings from the medicine: and moisten with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And it will be healed externally with an ointment, and internally with gargles, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Therefore this method of treatment is more wholesome than incision and farther from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the wound is also cured with what is more subtle than cauterization and incision: it is cured with smoking, in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamint, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sage, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and similar herbs to them: and gather all of them, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them with vinegar, and boil: and the pot should be coated with clay properly: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, on which a concave instrument is placed according to this way.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it from silver or copper: and the tip, in which is the grapefruit, is inserted into the mouth of the sick person until the vapor rises to the nostril through the cannula, until the nostril becomes obscured with vapor.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat on it many times until it dries out.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, do not make this treatment at the beginning of the formation of abscesses.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For indeed, it adds to the abscess: and you should not make it except at the decline of its hot swelling.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present to you, then take a cannula, and prepare in its tip a piece of cloth: so that the mouth of the sick person is not burned: for the cloth prevents the vapor from burning the mouth: and this is from good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	About the removal of splinters, and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
