Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if indeed the corruption is in the continuity of two joints, then there is no skill in it except for scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If indeed the corruption is in the claw of the hand, or in the claw of the foot: then the matter is quite difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary for you to investigate the corruption as it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it off, and clean it in any possible arrangement to you, and with whatever skill it is corrected for you: when it does not cause you contradiction of the vein, or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that the teeth and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their roughness, and their subtlety, and their size, and their proportionality, and their hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary for you to prepare every kind of suitable tool for that operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you the kind of tool you need, when you have with you the study of a long time.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of this art is a witness of the ways of diseases: for then you will already find through yourself that which suits it from the tools for every infirmity.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you in the last number of this chapter's tools, which you will set examples on top of which you will cut, and proof by which you experiment on others.
Forma Serrae.	The form of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Another form of the saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Another form of the saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Another form of the saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw should be made properly.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper arc be sharp and its edge from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and let it be made properly pyramidal.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the razor's blades.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be in the form of a star-shaped cap: and its points should be in the form of the points of an eagle.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit, unless they are rubbed with this razor when they are rotting, or a large mouth and it is big.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the medium-sized razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the razor with a hollow.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of the other fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the other curved-end razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the small fine razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the razor with which bones are shaved.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form of the large razor as well.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a chisel, and its end is like a saw: it will be shown in many places from the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the razor that suits its reason for shaving bones that are pierced.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular, and its ends are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from indigo.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it should be made from razor blades, and cutters, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	About cutting the ends and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either due to an external cause or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated that corruption with medicines and the cure does not take effect: and you see the corruption spreading to a member, which nothing stops: then it is necessary to cut off that member up to where the corruption reaches, so that the sick person may escape from death, or from the greater evil that is the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	The sign that this happens is, that the member blackens, until it is thought to be burned by fire, or putrefies after a gangrene: until the corruption reaches up to what follows that member, and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when you cut off that member, and also if the cause of the corruption is from the impact of certain poisonous creatures: such as the sea scorpion, and the viper, and the rattlesnake, and the like.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption, or the impact is in the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption, so that it may reach up to the other hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut off that from the root of the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption, until it reaches the finger of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it attacks that, then cut off the arm at the elbow, in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption passes through, and you see it around the elbow: then the sick person will die.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer besides that from the cure, is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do with the foot, when the corruption attacks in the finger, then cut off that at one joint: and if it reaches the toe of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it rises up to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	But if the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill in it, except for the release and leaving behind the weak to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way of cutting the member, or of sawing it, is this, that you bind the ligament below, which you wish to cut: and bind the ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And the servant should stretch one ligament downwards: and the servant should stretch the other ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you should separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the flesh is completely exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is cut, or it is sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to place cloth on all parts of the body, and not touch the sawed place with the saw: and an additional wound should not occur to the weak, and a warm abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if blood flows inside while you are operating, then you should cauterize the place quickly: or place on top of it some powders which absorb blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medical treatment, until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with a suitable ligament for it, and care for it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man in his foot, this same thing happening to him which I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because blackness occurred in his foot, with a burn which resembles the burning of fire: and that corruption first occurred in his finger, until it began to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man removed himself from himself, after he saw the corruption occurring in his member with its violence, which he found from his pain, and burning of it: and he cut it at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred in his own index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I attempted to restore the excess moisture with the medicine I placed on his hand after washing his body: but the excess did not rebound, and it began to spread to another finger: until the corruption began in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut off his hand: but I refused to do so, hoping for the return of that excess moisture: and I also feared for him during the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the power of man was above that case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Then, since he had lost hope in me, he returned to his own land: and he came to me from him, because he rushed, and he cut off his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this story, unless it be an aid to that which falls under this kind of sickness: and so that there may be a signification by which it is signified, and according to which it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	¶ On the care of wounds, and the quality of cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members, and the time of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or is pierced, and that which is in it from the pus exits, and there remains a vacant place as if it were a vessel: and the skin which is above it is like a fabric which has become thin: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, nor does it touch the mouth, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it deserves to be called a sinus: and it is not called a fistula: but if the time of its existence is prolonged until it touches some of these members, then it is called a fistula, or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you incise the entire skin as it unfolds: and especially when it has been thinned out and made like cloth: and you trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and there will be no decay from that final contact: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then care for it with Clisteri: and it is, that you consider to the Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that emits from it has a foul smell: then treat it with Egyptian medicine, which is acetic acid, oil, and zinc, equal parts receiving, they are gathered in a jar: and they are boiled over fire, until the medicine turns red: and it comes to the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and treat the Sinus with it: and bind its opening, and let the medicine into it at a quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: make it for days total, until the Sinus is cleansed, and the smell is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is treated with water of ashes, when you do not have this medicine present: and it is, that you take charcoal of vine wood, or charcoal of ilex wood: and throw it on it water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then wash it, and treat it with it, until you trust that the Sinus is already cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, nor water of ashes, then treat it with water and honey, which has already mixed with some of crushed zinc.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	1. Either apply honey mixed with wine and water to it, since honey has the property of cleansing and washing: and the wine makes it adhere to the wound, especially when there is an excess of its astringent and drying properties.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	1. If you do this repeatedly and trust that the wound has already been removed of corruption, then apply honey with that which makes flesh grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	1. And there is, that you take from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine: or apply honey to it with certain medicines and other ointments, of which I have written their properties in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	1. But if the wound is narrow, in which the catheter does not fit: then enlarge it slightly with a small iron: or place in it a lint soaked in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	1. And similarly if the wound is also large, then gather its lips with a suture: and leave out of it as much as will enter the catheter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	1. And similarly if the wound from which pus is flowing is elevated to the upper part: then dry it in a lower part which is in it, so that the pus flows out of it downwards: for when pus is compressed in the depth of the wound, it prevents flesh from growing in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	1. But if it is not possible for you to dry the wound around its lower part as you wish: then try to prepare the limb with a preparation so that it can drain pus from it with ease according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	1. Try to make sure that nothing at all from the pus is retained in it: and take consolidating remedies which are placed on the sign, corresponding to what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them upon a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it may cover the entire wound.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps directly into the opening of the wound, a little beyond the opening of the wound.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread on the opening with a soft ointment on another cloth, according to the size of the opening: and place it on top of it at a long distance from the opening of the wound, so that the exit of pus is eased from it: and do not remove the large cloth unless after several days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one that is over the opening of the wound is the one that you remove every hour, so that what has accumulated in it from pus may come out: and so that you know whether that which runs out from it is much or little: digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have again considered the place of the wound itself, whether the master feels pain in it, or whether there is no pain in it: and whether there is an abscess in it, or whether there is no abscess in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your medication is applied in this way, and you see the matter that comes out over the opening of the wound, then you know that the wound has adhered, or is approaching adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you heal the wound, then change the cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if after a long time virulent matter runs out from the wound, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, because there are people who slow down the generation of flesh in their wounds: and there are those who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if after many days undigested pus runs out from the wound, then you know that the wound does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If the adhesion of the sinuses is delayed and its duration is prolonged, then in the drying of medicines, the physicians should make them such that they are in the substance of their moisture and in the power of their dryness, just like the addition of excess from zegi to the unguent of diaphinicon.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the most recent that is cured, it is, that you take the unguent of diaphinicon and dissolve it with rose oil, and rub it on top of equal old wine in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with that, and use it with that.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it performs a similar action to this when you do not have the unguent of diaphinicon present for you, honey, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it with that.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense: grind everything, and powder it on top of honey while it is on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then draw a thread over it on the cloth, and tie it over the sinus: and draw a thread with the honey that you cooked, until it thickens: and powder it on top of it, and put it on top of it, and tie it on.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered in the long-leaved aristolochia, and the roots of the heavenly lily, and there is a lily: and the flour of the herb, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or mixed, grind them, and the mortar itself: and powder it on top of the honey that I have cooked, and use it with that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the duration of the sinus is prolonged and it is not healed by this treatment: then know that there is corruption in its depth: or already it has made an impression in the bones, or in the other hard members, or ligaments: then cure it with the treatment of fistulas, according to what was prescribed before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the Care of Paronychia and Worn Nails, and on Incision of the Finger, and on Section
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Paronychia is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb, or foot: and perhaps it may arise in the other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When, however, the condition persists and is neglected and treated with a hot abscess, or it rots and emits pus until it corrodes the root of the nail: and perhaps it may corrupt the whole of it, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, until there is an odor of putrefaction: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	Therefore, when you are treating it, since what we said about the division does not apply to your treatment, then it is necessary that you incise with a knife all the remaining excess from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Indeed, a cautery is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If, however, the bone is healthy and the nail is also healthy, and the additions of the nail already compress the flesh to the interior, and they begin to prick it, and they wound it: then it is necessary that you place a thin radium under the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and push it upwards: and incise the flesh with ease, and place on what remains of the flesh from medicines that burn, corrode, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, the corruption has already pressed into the bone, then it is necessary that you incise that bone, and remove it: for it never heals while the corrupted bone remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see signs of corrosion and decay spreading in the finger, then cut it off at one joint, according to what was previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the remaining part until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if a nail is injured by wear and tear, or by a blow: and there is severe pain in it, then it is necessary to perform bloodletting on the affected part.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp spatula from below upwards to the sight.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard against the cut reaching the flesh beneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain and it will be a cause of additional inflammation in that location.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then take care of the affected area with what alleviates pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	Indeed, the finger that grows in some people's hands may be entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail: and some of them grow at the root of the joint, or its growth is in some of the joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, the one that grows in some joints of the finger does not move: and the one that grows at the joint of the finger may move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the cutting of the one that is entirely fleshy is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, you should cut it at its root with a flat spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the treatment of the one whose growth is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, avoid cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in the one that grows at the last joint of the finger, then you should cut into its flesh roundly up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then use a saw with one of those suitable saws for that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the consolidation that occurs in the fingers is often due to birth, meaning it is born with it, or from the healing of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, you must separate that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen or cloths soaked in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly and separate between them, or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the place is consolidated as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if a consolidation occurs between certain fingers and the palm, then dry that consolidation according to how it is prepared and fits the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	§ On Incising Wounds.
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are veins that are not covered, thick, full of superfluous melancholic humors which occur in many parts of the body: and their greatest effect is in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and suffer and carry.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, the administrator should give a strong shaking of the body from black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then bleeding of the patient through the basilica.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of them with iron is indeed in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are dried and the black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other way is that the vein is raised and the whole is drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The incision of it is indeed in this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First, rub the leg with hot water many times until the thick bloody feces are dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the weak leg from its upper part of the hip, down to the lower part of the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then remove, that is, draw the blood out of your hand from the lower part of the leg, upwards, and from the upper part, it is necessary to bleed the sick first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail with it down to the lower part: until enough blood comes out that you see is sufficient, and as much as the strength of the sick can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it up: and tell him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat evacuation and bleeding when the veins are filled, and it harms this sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	However, his bleeding is done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the sick person if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse him in a bath: or foment his leg with hot water on it, until it reddens, and the veins are full: or exercise strong exercise if there is not present a bath, until the limb is warmed.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin in a straight line across the vein: or at the last of it by the knee, or in the lower part of it by the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrape the vein from all parts, until it appears to the sense: and at its appearance, which you see is reddening downwards to blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it goes out of the skin, you see it white like a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then immerse under it Radium, until when bled and goes out of the skin: suspend it with a blind hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another section near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then clean it with a brush and hang it up with another peg as you did before.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section or several sections if you need them.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then clean it and cut the last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you remove it from the section that is above or higher with all sections until it comes out completely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you in removing and cleaning: then insert a needle with strong thread doubled, and tie it, and remove it: or insert a brush under it: and turn your hand to all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, do not cut it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to clean it greatly, and it will cause harm on the weak from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have removed it all: then place it on the wound with a moistened cloth in wine and rose oil or oil: and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the grape is contracted, having a twisted shape to which there is an unrolling to all parts and it is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary to cut over it to all part of its twist and the places of its unrolling.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it up with pegs until you clean it all: and beware at your cut on it that you do not cut the vein or wounds: for it will be difficult for you to clean it or remove it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, use your wisdom.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of Incision for Healing a Vine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of Incision for a Blind Eye.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have curvature like other eyelids, nor is it sharp at the edges, so as not to wound the eye: and it is thick and flexible, mild: for if it were subtle, it would pierce the eye with its subtlety: indeed it should have excessive thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Leg Vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs on earthly hot lands, such as Alizaga, and the Arab lands, and in dry, hot, and few-tending lands, that is, where there is no grass or tree.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other places of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Its generation indeed is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just like what happens inside the body with snakes and worms of ascarides, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is that which happens in the leg, a severe inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is opened up.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from that place of its opening, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore it appears from that end of it, then you should roll over it a fragment of lead, whose weight is from the drachma keil, up to two drachmas and the knot: and let go the lead hanging from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something exits from it to the outsides, roll that in lead and knot it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged too much, then cut off a part of it and wrap up the remaining part.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it off at its root before it has fully emerged.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	Because if you cut it off, it contracts and enters the flesh, causing an abscess, putrefaction, and a bad ulcer in that place.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently and gradually removed until it fully emerges from its last part, and nothing remains of it in the body. In some people, this vein exits in a length of five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has reached me, because it has exited from a man after twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If it happens to you during your medical treatment: then insert the needle into its opening, and pierce it through the hole with the body, until all that is in it from the matter is evacuated. And administer putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the wound with the treatment of the abscess.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and exits from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore care for it as we said in the division, and with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ On cutting out worms that are generated under the skin, and it is called "Bouini's disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called "Bouini's disease" in a certain land among us because it often happens to worms, and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it wanders throughout the entire body, ascending and descending: and it is shown to the senses during its walking from one member to another, until it breaks down any place in the skin where it exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	Its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as it happens to worms and snakes, that is, roundworms and tapeworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared from its malevolence.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it walks in the body, and is raised to the head, and reaches the place: then perhaps it opens in that, and exits, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and extract it, then it is not done unless during its walking and appearance to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must bind what is above it, and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is sunk into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place a hot iron on the place until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater thing that is feared, is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind under it the eyebrow with a good ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And you must use a weak cleansing of his body, with dissolving medicines that remove foul humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he must guard himself from foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	§ On cutting for pain in the jaw.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This affliction is called by us in our land as "Nakir": and it is a pain that affects certain limbs, then passes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have already seen it myself, as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to an ill woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she extended her arm, and I saw inflammation of the small vein in the tendon of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for an hour, I saw one inflammation moving with a stick, like a snake, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than is possible: so that it is like living silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place, and fixed itself on her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran to the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was turning around her whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was therefore amazed at the swiftness of its change from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I had not seen this affliction with my eyes in that way according to this manner before that.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But indeed I have seen many who find the pain changing from one member to another: and I have not seen it with my eyes as I saw it in that woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it is, except that it is because the woman was from those who are from dry bodies' veins detected: hence therefore it appears to sense that swiftness changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate, and bodies humid, hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to cure her pain, and the patient feels it: then if it is appearing to you with your eye, as we said, then bind above it, and under it quickly: and dry above it, until that swiftness confined exits: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your own eyes: then care for it with body massage, and with that which expels worms, and rub it with foul-smelling powders, and powders of sappor, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows vary according to their kinds, and according to the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	However, their variety is such: because there are some that have large and small, concave, and deaf points.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are some that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And there are some that have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And there are some that have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that are according to the members in which they fall, are according to two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For indeed the members are from the principal concave members, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar things.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these members, and the signs of death appear to you, which I tell you after, then it is necessary that you follow the extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows it in many positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when those bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it, and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For from the signs of the brain when the arrow falls into it, and penetrates the mouth, and exits that which is above the brain, is: because these things happen from it strong soda, and scotomia, and vertigo, and redness in the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and permixtion of intellect, and vomiting of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may issue forth from the nostrils, or from the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white fluid like pus issues forth from the wound.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And a similar discharge of flesh issues forth from it.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from healing, and extract the arrow if it does not issue forth.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	But the signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple; and it feels with it as if it were itself fixed in a hard thing, not in a void.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow is similar to the motion of a blow: and black blood runs from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And there follows a chill of the extremities, and cold sweat, and shortness of breath.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore, that death is approaching without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is: that foamy blood runs from the wound: and the wounds following the neck swell up, and the color of the sick person changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a deep, cold breath: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the lung, which is in the chest: then it is near the small ribs: and there is great panting with intense pain, with a sigh: and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food issues forth from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the bowel and sticks in it: something of feces issues forth from the wound, or a mass, or an intestine that is already broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope of healing him, nor in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out from it, and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the weak person: then you will know that it is a mortal wound.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The other parts of the body, such as the face, neck, throat, shoulder blade, ribs, backbone, hip, and leg, and similar parts from the limbs are saved according to many arrangements: when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve: and it is not a poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen these arrows, to signify for your healing.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell to a man in the lacrimal duct of his eye, in the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore, I extracted it from the other side, under the ear fat: and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted the arrow from a Jew, which fell to him under the fat of his eye, under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not follow it except its small tip with which it sticks to its wood: and it was a large arrow from the arrows of Turks, with a weak iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jew was healed, and no harmful event came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted the arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and it is that which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore, I followed over it between two ribs: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was subtle with her until I extracted her, and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man which had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After therefore three days had passed over him, and nothing was changed on him from his dispositions, I followed after the arrow: and I probed it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil accident happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man on whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound was hardened over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After therefore it was after seven years, the arrow came out of the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman on whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound was hardened over it, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing was changed from her dispositions, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw a man another, on whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound was hardened, and it remained, not finding much pain: and similar things to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the king's principal officers, which had fallen on him in the middle of his nose, and it was already slightly declined to the right side: and the arrow was hidden entirely.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called for healing after the fall of the arrow up to three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I therefore found the wound of the arrow very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore probed it with a thin probe, and I did not find it: and he himself found pain and pricking under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that this prick was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Therefore, I placed the plaster with the plaster that had the power of attraction and digestion, trusting that the abscess would form in that place, and it appeared to me to be a sign of an arrow, so I cut above it: and it did not happen that the arrow followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore, I applied the plaster to him for many days: and it did not happen that the wound became worse, and the wound healed in the meantime: and he remained weak from its extraction for a period of days, until he felt the arrow inside his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about it.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	Therefore, I placed on that wound an acute and corrosive medicine for many days, until it was open: and when I probed it, and felt the delicate tip of the arrow that stuck to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the open wound that medicine, until the tip of the arrow appeared visible to us: and it passed by me with him for a period of time, approximately four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, after the wound had been enlarged, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey its exit: then I did not cease to sharpen, and invent on it with ways of ingenuity, until I began one day with well-made forceps, according to the form that they will have at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed, the doctors judge that the cartilage of the nose will not be healed.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore, I healed it again, and the wound healed, and the sick man was healed with complete health: and nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you about the method of extracting certain arrows: place that rule and meaning on what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this craft and their distinctions are not comprehended in narration: nor does that book understand it, and a wise craftsman compares with little above much: and with what is present, he finds on that which is absent: and he discovers a new operation and a new instrument among the descents of external things of this craft when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not exit from the members in which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits where it entered, is either an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place and is attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	But if it does not obey the exit from the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you let it go for several days until the flesh which is in its circumference rots: and its attraction is alleviated and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it sticks to bone, and does not obey you for exit, then let it go also for several days: and repeat it with attraction and motion every day until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	But if it does not obey you for exit after days: then it is necessary that you bore through the circumference of the arrow in the bone from all parts with a fine drill until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull, and it has already proceeded into one of the cerebral ventricles, and some of those accidents appear which I said: then abstain from the attraction of the arrow and let it go until it is equal to its after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow has reached the liver, then death will not be prolonged for it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow has not been fixed, unless it is only in the body of a bone and does not penetrate to the liver: and he remains weak for several days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then use your skills in the attraction of the arrow and its extraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly, and does not obey you for attraction: then give a counter-poison in the circumference of the arrow, as I have told you: then care for the wound, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow has already hidden itself in a place of the body, and is concealed and hidden from sensation: then search for it with probing.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then draw it out with some instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot touch it, due to the constriction of the wound, and due to the length of the arrow in the deep place: and there is no bone, nerve, or vein: then cut over it, until the wound is enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	But if there are ears to which it is attached, then free the flesh that is fixed in them from all parts, with every skill that you can, and skills, if it cannot be removed over the flesh in the fracture of the ears, and the twisting of them, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you are administering the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you make it come out: and subtle last subtleties, so that the arrow does not break, and it becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot apply it to her within an hour, then let her go for several days until the affected parts around her decay.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the application: it will heal the wound. However, if it causes opposite effects on your blood flow, then administer what we mentioned in the chapter on treatment, and guard your virtue from incision of vein, nerve, or string.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer your skill in every possible way that is possible for you to avoid the arrow: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that when you pull the arrow, it should be weak according to its form, as it was at the time of the arrow's wound in the same place.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	However, if it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible to you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that comes out from the other part, or already proceeds from it to the exterior: or makes stiffness of the extremity of the arrow through sense from the upper part of the skin near, and you see it projecting: then cut on it, and let the incision be according to the amount that the pincers can take in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it: for it becomes easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	However, if it retains in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until the arrow hits the bone, and enlarges itself: then pull it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let her go for several days: then repeat it until she exits.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	However, if the wood of the arrow is in her, then push it with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however a log has fallen and you wish to administer an impulse to it, then introduce the concave instrument into it so that its concavity enters the tail of the Arrow: then strike it along with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If however the Arrow is concave, then strike it with the entering instrument.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The Arrow is relieved by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If however the Arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to hollow out the entire flesh in which the poison is: if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it with that which is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If however the Arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is close to that which you touch with the thread, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and avoid from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then care for its wound, if you see it, and heal that, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the shape of the Forceps by which Arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let their extremities be similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they take hold of the Arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many shapes are made from them, large and small, and medium-sized, according to the quantity of the size of the Arrow, and its lightness, and the width of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of the Striking concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape of the Striking deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the deaf extremity like a Radius, so that its entrance into the concave Arrow is relieved, and it is struck with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this striking concave is concave like the feather of a bird: so that its entrance into the Arrow is relieved, and its impulse.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Chapter on the Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins that are customarily bled in the body are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.
