Of these, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins that are located behind the ears, called "the herbs"; and two arteries that are visible in two temples; and two veins that are located in the two lachrymal ducts of both eyes, called "the spectators"; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two jugular veins that are located in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are located on the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are located on the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called "the alchemists".
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are located under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are bled in the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic vein, and it is located on the sulci side; and the people call it the "vein of the head".
Et Fusca.	And the dark one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the middle vein is composed of a branch of the basilica and a branch of the cephalic vein; and the people call it the "vein of the body".
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the basilica is located on the domical side; and it is also called the "titillating vein".
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	The people call it the "vein of the belly".
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the "brachial string" is located above the elbow; and it is the one that is bled, and it is the one that appears above the wrist with the palm facing up.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Saluatella: and it is a vein that is between the ring finger and the little finger: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the leg and foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the vein that is under the pollicis curvature from the side of the sylvestris.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its location is at the calcaneum from the side of the domestic.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nesse: and its location is at the calcaneum from the side of the sylvestris.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the leg there are other three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	¶ On bleeding from two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Bleeding indeed from two veins which are after the ears is a remedy for ancient catarrhs, and hemigraine, and sahafati, and old head sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bleeding it is according to what I say.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the sick be rubbed: and the back of his head is rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth rubbing well.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the sick person will tie his neck with a string, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are after the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore seek them with your finger, and where you feel them being pricked by your finger, there mark with caustic.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a bleeding lancet, and it is the one that is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the bleeding lancet reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wipe your hand with the vein and skin to the upper, and cut the vein with the Incidens cutting.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be an amount equal to two fingers of a scribe, or about that: and make it bleed as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with cotton, and let it go, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now at the beginning of the book, the incision of them, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On bleeding two arteries in times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arteries which are in the two times of bleeding, is a benefit to the ancient hemigram: and bad salt, and frequent ointment: and the course of the flowing sharp drops to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding them is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The sick person ties his neck a lot, until two veins appear to the sense of appearance manifest: and shows the pulse of them under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then the signs with the cauterizer.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein to the upper with your index finger, and insert the bleeding incoming from below, and lift the vein to the upper.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did in two other veins: and make it flow out of the blood according to the amount of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then dissolve the sick person's bandage, and put your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put on it the cotton and bandages, and bind it above with strong constriction: and let it go, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the reminder of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On bleeding the vein of the forehead after bleeding the cephalic.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The true indication for phlebotomy of the veins in front of the face is after phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein, for ancient facial ailments: and for hemicrania, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is as I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The sick person should flex his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Its form is as follows.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the sharp point that is at the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and strike it with a lancet, or with another instrument in its manner: and let the blood run according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the puncture of the sick person, and bind it until he is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it opens with a broad lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that the lancet be sharp at the end, like other lancets, but rather flat at the end.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And use the lancet according to the transection: for the mouth is near: and perhaps the lancet will break in it if it is delicate.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Concerning phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The indication for phlebotomy of the two veins that are in the two lacrimal ducts of both eyes is for eye pain and redness: and sebel in the eye, and facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is that the sick person should flex his neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then use the lancet on them: and you should be standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let bloodletting be performed according to the transverse direction, for a short length, with a small lancet, slightly wide, because there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the bloodletting is too delicate at the extremity, perhaps it will be broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood run out as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a bandage on them, and tie them up at night in one night, and dissolve them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On bloodletting of the nasal bones.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	But bloodletting of the nasal bones is for comparing to acute fever, and strong soda, and face aches, such as hemigranes, and redness that occurs in the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its bloodletting is to tie up a weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold its nose with your left hand, and take a thin bloodletting, long: and fix it in the middle of its rabbit, between that which distinguishes its nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary, that your last hand with the bloodletting slightly: and let the blood run out according to your necessity.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie it up at night in one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly indeed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On bloodletting of the guide bones.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	However, the benefit of bloodletting of both guide bones is for constriction of breathing, and inception of leprosy, and melancholic aches, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and corroding, that is, herpes zoster.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of its bloodletting is that it ties up a weak one under both in its neck with a bandage: and let the craftsman stand on the head of the sick man, and the sick man sit on him.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then, the vein is punctured at a length equal to the width of a wide incision.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then, extract an amount of blood that is moderate, or according to what you see as necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then, do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards, loosen the ligament, and tie two veins together with a median ligature: so that the weak one is not preferred.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Concerning the vein bleeding of Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins, however, are the support of Albucasis's bleeding: because they bring relief to colic in the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and bad sores: and fissures of the lips, and bad sores, even those which are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their bleeding is that you make the sick person sit in front of you: and tie his neck with a ligature.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then, roll his lip back, and look at the two veins: one of which is on the right side of his lip, and the other on the left: and the demonstration of each is by the darkness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because there are small veins, black, around them.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, make an incision on each of them with a cutting instrument.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt over you, and you do not know which of them is: then direct to the incision of the larger ones, and their more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And likewise do with the two veins which are on the upper lip: and most of all custom does that with it: and make an incision on the two veins which are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding bleeding from the vein under the tongue after bleeding from the cephalic vein.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	However, bleeding from the two veins under the tongue is beneficial: it is because bleeding from the cephalic vein is for conditions that are in the throat, and pain in the neck, and conditions of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bleeding from these veins is that the sick person should sit with you facing the sun, and elevate his tongue, and look under his tongue from one side for a vein, and from the other side for a vein: and the color of both should be declining towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore bleed from both: and watch, lest your last hand in bleeding from these.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps it may happen that blood flows from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Regarding the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	However, the three veins that are bled from in the elbow, are in which bleeding has become customary in all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bleeding from them is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either pricking with a flat-tipped myrtle bleeder: or oilily to the fineness of decline: or cutting with a knife bleeder, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	So Alnesil is, which is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are species wide and fine according to the size and tightness of the veins: the shape of the myrtle bleeder should be wide, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, protruding, apparent, thick, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This bloodletting lancet is of lesser width and more delicate at its extreme tips.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for the vein bloodletting of delicate needles, which contain thin, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On the bloodletting of the basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, the basilica, which is one of these three vein bloodletting, is its jewel.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from illnesses that are under the chin and neck, from the chest and abdomen, and follows this, as a bloodletting physician with a lancet, he should be cautious and have fear of it, as under it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs and adds to the bloodletting puncture, he will cut that artery, and an accident of blood flow will occur.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary, not to bloodlet it with a sharp lancet, but to cut it with an alnasil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If it does not appear with a clear appearance of the basilica, then you should exchange it with another one, or seek some branch of it: or bloodlet in place of its arm brachial.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clear and cut it with an alnasil lancet, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you wish for the bloodletting of its own, then you should before the stricture of the arm, to touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then sign over the place with a cauterizer, then the arm, and cut the vein with a hollow cut with an alnasil lancet, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful that the impact does not fall over the distance from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, with you tighten the bandage, inflation in the place that you signed with a cauterizer, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood gushing out from the phlebotomy, like a child's urine, and it is thin and red, then you know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore rush, and place your finger on it for a long time, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut off (often indeed it is cut off), then tighten the arm, and let it go: and let the weak one be cautious of its motion: and let him be on guard against his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not cut off, and it overpowers you: and there is no medicine for you present in your moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are contracted, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the boxer's corticem, and press him: take half of it, and tie it over the place of the vein neatly, with a bandage and cotton until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of it with him whose memory preceded from the place of dust abscinding blood flow: and cutting of his blood is not difficult in many positions, because of the small wound location, and possibility of bandage from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On phlebotomy of the vein Black
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the veins Black phlebotomy is a benefit, which draws blood from the upper part of the head, and lower body: because it is composed of the branch Basilica, and the branch Cephalic, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is appropriate for the phlebotomist to have fear of her, because beneath her is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	Therefore, if the phlebotomist adds to the puncture and discovers a nerve, it may cause stupor in her, making her recovery difficult, and perhaps she will not be healed completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then you must place your phlebotomy where the phlebotomist makes the cut, with Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	About the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	However, the phlebotomy of the Cephalic Vein is a remedy, because it draws blood from the head, and brings it to eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this vein, if you wish, to puncture it with a phlebotomy oil lamp, or with a phlebotomy myrtle: because it is safer than all veins, since it is not beneath an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it is appropriate for you with the phlebotomy to avoid with the phlebotomy the tail of the lizard, and seek a gentler spot: and it does not harm him, if it is not found with the first blow, to repeat the phlebotomy on her several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, perhaps an abscess forms in some people when it is not punctured in the first blow, but it does not harm him that abscess in some place.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	About the Usefulness of Phlebotomy, and Precautions to be Observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of bloodletting and its accidents depend on the correction of which you must think.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Therefore, the first thing you should know about bloodletting is that it is not administered unless for the preservation of health, its continuity, and caution against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that bloodletting may be performed on one of the three veins in the arm, namely the cephalic, fusca, and basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that bloodletting may be performed at the beginning of spring on fasting, in the spring, and in summer; and in autumn and winter after eating, when the signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting should be performed on the first or third day after three hours have passed since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, bloodletting that is administered in illnesses does not have a determined time; but when convenience and necessity prompt it, at night or during the day, and in every hour, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not proper for children to undergo bloodletting until they reach the age of fourteen.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman undergo bloodletting, except from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And the elderly who have already crossed sixty years should not undergo bloodletting.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to undergo bloodletting for any reason, it is proper that they clean their intestines before bloodletting with a mild enema if there is much feces retained in them: so that the veins at the time of bloodletting do not draw out from the intestines harmful superfluities which are noxious to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient with toctina, that is, nauseous satiety, undergo bloodletting, nor one who has overeaten, nor one who is trying to avoid drunkenness, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor is the weak one with hydrocephalus.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bleeding should be avoided again after colic pain, vomiting, diarrhea, frequent intercourse, labor, exercise, and sleeplessness, and fasting, and everything that dissolves strength from the body or the animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if the blood is thick with food and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for him to have that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he should take a bath, if nothing prohibits him: or he should be exercised with some exercise, so that the blood becomes subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place bleeding on his chest, around the third day, as we said: and try to evacuate his chest that day from all animal misfortunes: such as anguish, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily misfortunes, such as labor, and punishment, and superfluousness, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let his seat be made to have the presence of those things with which he became accustomed to use from the custom of men from aromaticity, and perfuming, and dancing and similar things by the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the bleeder should sit on a litter, which is higher than the litter for bleeding: then he should draw his arm, and rub it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should tie a ligature with a bandage, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the binding be temperate, because when the binding is unequal, or by excess in the binding, then it prevents the course of the blood: or in the softening, then also it prevents the course of the blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the binding, it is necessary to rub the bleeder with his hands simultaneously, until the veins swell, and declare themselves to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then, the phlebotomist washes the phlebotomy site with a little oil, as is proper and ancient.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then, he places his index finger of his left hand on the vein, under the spot where he wants to perform the phlebotomy, slightly: so that the vein does not escape, and the blow is contained.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For since the veins are like a slippery cord when you find them at phlebotomy: and from them is what is full of pliability: and when you place the phlebotomy on it, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and deceives the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it opens it, it is tight: therefore for this reason it is necessary that the phlebotomist be firm, and be careful in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should lay down the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein opens from one side, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat that side in another place slightly, or above it with haste: if the spot does not become inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it becomes inflamed, or the patient is weak, then let him go on the day, or in two days: and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps the abscess will attract heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And he should not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he should repeat the phlebotomy, if he likes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or the blood flows thinly: and you fear that not enough blood will come out: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same hole according to straightness, and add a little in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do that with haste, before the spot becomes inflamed, for an inflamed spot is in many people at small operations.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it is already suppurating, then do not press on it at all, for nothing excuses it in your eyes.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something oily on it: for it will soothe the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the oil in all your phlebotomies, where the phlebotomist prohibits the course of the blood: and they make it tyriaca alfarach, and sagzenea, when it is placed on one of them on the spot.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is thinned and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	But if an abscess occurs in the place of phlebotomy, for it often happens, especially to those who are not phlebotomized except at that time, or is a small opening of the vein, then hurry and place a sponge soaked in water and salt on the spot, heated for a while: and bind it for an hour: for it will dissolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do this after the exit of blood from the vein itself, with its own supplement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	But if something remains in the spot after a few days, black or green, it does not harm it: and if you wish, place something aloe, or myrrh solutes on it: or something from the juice of menthastr, that is, calamint or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	But often indeed abscesses and boils occur at the phlebotomy of the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand on it, then if you find softness at your compression on it, then that boil is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore beware, so that you place something from what we said on it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But apply a plaster to it with the one that has astringency, so that the wound is hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the other cure until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to extract all blood from every man according to the quantity of its virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color staining on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it go out, until it turns red: and similarly if you see it thick, then let it go out, until it becomes thin: and similarly if it is sharp, then let its sharpness be removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting once, to increase the venipuncture, and to be on the left side: and in him who is weak, the opposite.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract it at certain times, and that there be a narrow opening: and better what is administered in bloodletting from the vein is that it be transverse section, not puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than bloodletting by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is customary to arrive at bloodletting with syncope, it is necessary that he eat before bloodletting a little bread soaked in water of pomegranate: or secaniba if he is hot: and extract him from the blood in three times, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if he is of a cold complexion, then he should take before bloodletting bread soaked in syrup of myrrh, or in syrup of honey aromatized with species, or in aromatic syrup fragrant.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If a case of syncope occurs among phlebotomists, and the cause is the escape of blood, then it is necessary for them to take a drink of meat water and odoriferous syrup: and they should use aromatics with algalia, and bandage their chest with that: and they should use the other things we mentioned in the division in the chapter on syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But if someone wants to evacuate their arm and dissolve their blood secondarily: it is necessary for them whose phlebotomy is for evacuation of much blood, and whose virtue is weak, that they dissolve the blood gradually by the amount of virtue in consecutive days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But if someone wants to evacuate their arm and dissolve their blood secondarily, and their body is strong: then they should do it after seven hours, or nine from their first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But if someone wants to draw blood from their body towards the opposite part of which they lean: it is necessary for them to evacuate on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and makes fever to happen: it is necessary for the blood to come out of it in one draft, and a large amount to be drawn from it: and the opening should be enlarged until syncope happens: after you have been preserving all the conditions of phlebotomy: and that you place your hand on the vein during the course of the blood, so that death does not happen in the place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For often this happens when the phlebotomist does not know, and negligence falls.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you want to evacuate the arm, and dissolve the blood secondarily, when the opening of the vein has already been closed, and difficult exit of the blood is made, that it be applied with force, and extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a great evil, but let it go until he is bled again.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the sharpness of the bleeding needle that which has coagulated from the blood in the vein opening, and place on it something dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place on it something from the Tyrian alfaroch, or sagzenea, and place it with gentle compression until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if indeed the vein has already become an abscess, then let it go, and do not cover it until the abscess is formed.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	But if necessity provokes to solve the blood again, and there is no excuse, then either with the bleeding needle above that place, or in the other arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the arm's vein is bled at the place of the Fuscus and Basilica, when they are not found, and they are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its bleeding is that the sick hand enters into hot water, until it reddens easily, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is tied above it with a small bandage in the middle compression.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the bleeding needle is done according to transversal, not latitudinal, nor according to the length: and it is a wide opening, and your bleeding is above the joining of the hand for a moment.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	But if the exit of the blood is forbidden, then repeat the hand in hot water, and let the blood run in the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the days of summer, then you will be excused from repeating the hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	Indeed, very much is placed on the course of the blood in hot water in the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	This bloodletting from this vein is safer than all other veins, since there is no pulsating vein nor nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Indeed, the bloodletting from the Salute's right hand is beneficial for the liver's ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this bloodletting is such that you should tie the vein with a ligature or with your hand, after you have inserted it into warm water, until the vein is filled and the sensation is very strong.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then, the bloodletting is to be performed by puncturing.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you puncture it entirely, it will not harm her in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And save, do not use your last hand with the bloodletting instrument.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under it are the nerves of the fingers exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat with your hand to warm water, and let the blood flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in warm water, the blood will coagulate in the opening of the vein and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you have extracted the necessary quantity of blood, then place oil and salt on the vein: so that it does not clot quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise, you must do with every tight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The remedy for this bloodletting from the left hand is: because it is beneficial for the ailments of the spleen; and likewise do in its bloodletting, as you did in the second one, equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The remedy for the bloodletting of the saphenae is: for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as uterine ailments, retention of menstruation, kidney weaknesses, and old ulcers of the thighs and legs, and similar from ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of the bloodletting is such that the sick person should put his foot in warm water and perform friction on it until the veins are full, then tie above the ankle with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The veins are indeed located at the heel, visible towards the big toe, and branch out from there into many branches in the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, perform bloodletting in a larger branch of it, or at the heel in its collection, as it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If bloodletting is performed on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are under it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your bloodletting where the bloodletting comes out of the transuvers, as if you wanted to cut it: and let the bloodletting be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the exit of blood is forbidden, then repeat the foot in warm water: and let the blood run into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the bloodletting needle misses the vein in the first attempt, then repeat the bloodletting with blood to the upper part for a little, as it is a safe place, and you do not fear harm from it when you avoid the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the other equal Saphena of the foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the veins of the Sciatica are, as we said, located at the heel on the side of the wood.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the relief of bloodletting from it is for pain in the ankle, when it is due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of bloodletting from it is that the sick person should enter the bath quickly and bind his leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel with four fingers, with a thin long bandage, for it does not appear except because of that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it is apparent, then perform a phlebotomy on it according to whatever method is possible for you, or by transection: and it is better, or that you cut it with an incision, or separate it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safer, and it is hidden greatly in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it, and it is not apparent at all to the senses: then perform a phlebotomy on some of its branches, and that one which appears in the back of the foot, and towards the ear: and beware of the nerves, and make it bleed a quantity of blood as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then dissolve the constriction, and place the skin on the location of the phlebotomy, and tie the location.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is healed quickly there.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ Of Ventilation, and its quality of use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventilations are made from horns, and from air, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventilation is indeed made in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and extraction of blood: and the other is ventilation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventilation which is without scarification, is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	For it is indeed with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And those ventilations which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood are fourteen locations of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the ventilation of Alnocrati, and it is the last of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the ventilations of Alhagdahim, and they are two layers of the neck from two parts at once: and the ventilation of the mind, and it is under the jaw in the lower part of the mouth: and the ventilation of two spatulas: and the ventilation of Alachosos on the end of the tail: and the ventilation of two forks, and they are in the middle of two arms: and the ventilation of two legs: and the ventilation of two wings.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And wind suction does not draw blood from your wounds that are spread thinly in the flesh, and for this reason its power does not remain, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to apply wind suction whether with fire or without fire in any ailment that arises from overfullness until the entire body has been emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	But if necessity provokes wind suction from the ailment or because of custom, we apply it at every hour in the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and at any time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Which is because there are people who when blood multiplies in them until they need its extraction by wind suction, find heaviness and pain in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them is found overfullness and redness in their face, on their head, and on their neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them is found itching in their face, and on their forehead, and darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them is found sweating at the place of their wind suction.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them is found whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them is found whose tongue has a taste of blood: or their tongue swells and vomiting blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them is found whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them is found who sees in their sleep blood and redness, and killed people, and wounds, and things similar to those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something from them, and if it is properly in the middle of the month: we command then for wind suction to be done after they have passed two or three hours past midday.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The bandage for ventosation of the ankle is as follows: since it contributes to heaviness in the head and that which is poured out affects the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	Indeed, it should be after complete evacuation of the body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed a place for cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use it for those who are of cold constitution or in whom there is a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it does him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for that reason, it is not allowed to use it for the elderly or in whose head there are cold ailments.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But those who become accustomed to it, become drowsy on it.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for that reason, you should command the ventosator to lay his hand with the ventosa briefly on the lower parts, fearing the generation of drowsiness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alkehel is a place for phlebotomy of the femoral vein, and phlebotomy of the basilic vein, and for that reason it brings asthma, and constriction of breathing, and cracking of the instrument of breathing, and cough, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be pushed slightly upward, because if it is placed lower, it causes weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosation of alhagdahim brings pain from accidental headaches, and obtalmiae, and hemigraneae, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is a place for phlebotomy of the basilic vein.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should command the ventosator not to press his hand with the scarification, so that he does not pierce the artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventilation under the chin, applies alcohol to the mouth, and prevents corruption of the jaw, and similar things from discomforts that are in the mouth: and it stands in place of phlebotomy, which are in two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventilation with spoons, applies to the alchefachem, which is made from folding and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	True ventilation of the two internal parts of the forearm, applies to the bandage of phlebotomy of three veins, Basilicae, and Fuscae, and Cephalicae: because it attracts blood from all the small veins that are in the flesh: and those small veins attract from other larger veins, until the attraction reaches three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you command the Ventosator not to proceed too much in scarification: because the place is bare of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The ventosator that ventilates on the buttocks, applies to hemorrhoids of the anus, and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you command the Ventosator to be large and made of air: because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the thin ventosators are broken: and scarification is done with a large scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The ventosators of the legs reduce the manifest diminution: because they attract blood from the whole body, and apply to old pains in the kidneys, and matrix, and bladder: provoke menstruation, and apply bothor, and ademenul: and stand in place of phlebotomy of the two saphenar veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body a lot, and cause syncope in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The remedy for the wound of a horse's neck is close to the remedy for the wound of two horses' legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position for the wound is that you should place the horse in a first empty stall and suck the wound with moderate suction: and do not prolong the position of the wounds, but place them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the humors come to the place with equal advent: and do not cease to repeat this and continue until you see the place already red and inflated, and the appearance of blood redness: then therefore scarify, and repeat suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the position of the body.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For if it is a person of tender flesh, of rare pore, it is necessary that you scarify him once, not more: so that the place does not hurt.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the horse to enlarge the scarification and to puncture a little: and regulate suction with ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary that you scarify him twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first juice indeed the way is opened to the subtle thinning of the blood and its moistening: and in the second indeed the thorough investigation of the exact extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	But if the blood is very foul, then make the third scarification: so that it follows the last.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we want to extract blood gradually or a little, one scarification is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we want many extractions of blood, we will scarify with multiple scarifications.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary that you scarify with deep scarifications: and the end equal in scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that thing that must be administered from oils at the position of the Wind-pipes, and what should one be cautious of when applying it?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case where the skin is rough, hard, dark, and its pores are tightly closed, it is necessary to anoint the Wind-pipe areas with oils that are open, gentle, and resolving: if it is in the time of summer, such as the oil of alkermes, or the violent oil, or the oil of sweet apricot kernels, or the oil of cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then the oil of narcissus, or the oil of lily, or the oil of camomile, or the sarbatinum: and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	But if the excess is rough, cold: then the oil should be myrrh, or the oil of balsam, or the white oil, or the oil of anise: and similar things.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	But if the Wind-pipe is of large pores, and of tender flesh: then it is necessary to prohibit oil, and it is necessary for them to wash the Wind-pipe areas after application with rosewater, or with cold water, or with water of the comforter, or with water of cucumber, or with water of portulaca: and similar things.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But that person whose blood is of much moisture, they should wash the Wind-pipes with vinegar, or with water of myrtle and sumach: and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	But that person whose excesses are rough, they should wash their Wind-pipes with old wine, or with water of sambucus, or the decoction of anise, or of chamomile: and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to be cautious of Wind-pipe application in the bath, or at the edge of the bath: indeed it is necessary to administer after exiting from the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	It is not necessary for someone to sleep after a nosebleed.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What should be done before a nosebleed to control it or to have it bled by a phlebotomist?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	Then, after the nosebleed, it is important to consider whether the person was bled or had a nosebleed beforehand. If they were choleric, the sharpness and inflammation in their blood will be increased. In this case, they should take cooling substances such as pomegranate rind, and also eat aceto (vinegar) with lettuce, secania (a type of herb), and julep (a sweetened drink) regularly.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And give them foods such as chicken eggs and cooked meats, and condiments with agreste (a type of herb).
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	If their constitution is cold, they should drink a syrup made from honey, almonds, or secania seeds, and also take a medium-strength aromatic wine that is between old and new. They should also be advised to eat little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And give them foods such as chicken eggs and canebir (a type of herb), and also small birds, that is, sparrows, and the young of doves.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And they should drink more than they eat on the day of the nosebleed and bloodletting. In some people, it is recommended to give them a drink made from tyriaca alfaroch (a type of herb), or a medicine made from musk (a type of perfume), or aleselith (a type of herb) before the nosebleed, or after bloodletting, to strengthen their main limbs and thin their blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	They should not drink it hot.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On nosebleeds without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Ventosae, which are without incision, are placed on the parietal, spleen, podagra, abdomen, umbilicus, and renal areas, as well as the perineum and anchored peg: because these parts do not tolerate incisions made upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And they are not sought through these, except for attachment of blood from a limb to a limb: such as we place a ventosae on the breasts in the case of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to dissolve the cold ventosities that have formed in a limb due to freezing: such as we place a ventosae on the abdomen and umbilicus.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For indeed, they rarefy the limb, and warm it, and remove pain because they have dissolved that ventosity.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	They are also placed on the kidneys when there is a stone or rock in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For perhaps by virtue of their attraction they may open the obstruction, or remove the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly, when it is placed on the parietal and spleen in both places where ventosity needs to be drained from them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventosae are administered empty with only a small incision.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in pleurisy: and this is that the ventosae be filled with warm water alone, or with water in which herbs have been boiled that are suitable.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of a ventosae administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its mouth be two open fingers, according to how we have shaped it: and let its depth be half a palm: and let there be on its side in the place that is approximately in the middle of it, a small hole, according to the size that enters it: let it be made of air simultaneously, or citrine, coarse margin, linen, equal, clean: so that it does not hurt the limb at its position on top of it: and let there be in the middle of it a transverse rod from air, or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this sponge becomes very large and much larger than we have described, and somewhat smaller than the one we mentioned, according to his illness and age who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For boys and those who are thin, other sponges are used, which are not as large as those for men and people with thick bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	However, the quality of applying this sponge with fire to a limb is that you should light the linen with fire from flax cloth properly, or a small candle from earthenware: and place it on the middle of the transverse strip which is in the middle of the sponge, so that the fire may be applied to the lower part of the sponge, so as not to burn the body of the sick person.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.
